Submission of the Record - October 31, 2022 Attachment 1

From: Adam Slamin <adam.j.slamin@gmail.com>
Sent: Monday, October 31, 2022 5:40 PM
To: City Council <CityCouncil@CambridgeMA.GOV>
Cc: info@cambridgebikesafety.org; Clerk <clerk@cambridgema.gov>
Subject: Brattle St project delay
Hello,
Thanks to all of the great work the city has been doing recently on bike lane installation, and I'm excited for the new
work being planned on Hampshire St, which I commute through daily.
I've recently learned that the Brattle St. project is expected to be delayed due to issues delivering materials. While this
delay is unfortunate, I encourage the city to move ahead with street marking and installing temporary safety barriers in
the meantime. Especially with the days getting shorter, even these temporary measures could make a huge difference
for the safety of residents.
Best,
Adam S

CMA 2022 #211
IN CITY COUNCIL

I am hereby requesting the appropriation of the Safer Communities Initiative Edward J. Byrne
Justice Assistance Grant, received from the state Executive Office of Public Safety and
Security’s Office of Grants and Research, through the Middlesex County District Attorney’s

violence, and support the community.

Packet Pg. 94

1.2

CMA 2022 #212
IN CITY COUNCIL
November 7, 2022
I am writing to recommend two Cambridge residents, Keisha Greaves and Robert Goss, for appointment
to the advisory board of the Cambridge Commission for Persons with Disabilities (CCPD), each for a
three year term.
A summary of the process used to fill these two appointments is described below. While this recruitment
process pre-dates the guidelines outlined in City Manager’s Agenda Item #207 of October 24, 2022, the
CCPD staff implemented a comprehensive recruitment process that has resulted in two strong candidates.
Because the board has canceled two of its monthly meetings since the beginning of the year due to lack of
quorum, it is important that we fill these vacancies as soon as possible. There is one additional vacancy
on the board, and it is our intention to fill that position using the guidelines outlined in CMA 2022 #207.
About the Cambridge Commission for Persons with Disabilities
The Cambridge Commission for Persons with Disabilities (CCPD) was established under Ch. 2.96 of the
Cambridge Municipal Code. The eleven (11) member board consists of: one representative from the
Department of Public Works, one representative from the Department of Human Service Programs, at
least five people with disabilities, and up to four individuals who are family members, friends, or
otherwise connected to people with disabilities.
The two positions being filled on the board were previously held by people with disabilities. The two
candidates recommended to these positions self-identify as people with disabilities.

Copy of Posting
City Manager Seeks Applicants for CCPD Advisory Board
Cambridge City Manager Louis A. DePasquale is seeking to fill vacancies on the Cambridge
Commission for Persons with Disabilities (CCPD) advisory board.
CCPD works to increase access to all aspects of Cambridge community life for people with
disabilities. CCPD raises awareness about disability issues and promotes equal opportunity for
people with a range of abilities, including physical, mental, and sensory. CCPD provides
information, referrals, guidance, and technical assistance to individuals and their families,
employers, public agencies, businesses and private non-profit organizations.

Packet Pg. 95

1.2

The CCPD board has 11 members who serve as volunteers for three-year terms. CCPD Board
Members:
• Must be Cambridge residents
• Represent different disabilities, diverse cultures and races, and all parts of Cambridge
• Attend monthly meetings, held the second Thursday of every month at 5:30 p.m.
• Take part in Working Groups and work on projects as needed
• Work with other members and the office staff to carry out the CCPD Ordinance (CMC
Chapter 2.96).
Apply to the CCPD advisory board at www.cambridgema.gov/apply. As part of your application,
please submit:
•
a cover letter, and
• a résumé or summary of relevant experience that includes disability-related issues or
projects that interest you
For a paper application, visit the City Manager’s Office at Cambridge City Hall, 795
Massachusetts Avenue. If you need help filling out your application or have any questions, please
contact CCPD at:
• ccpd@cambridgema.gov,
• 617-349-4692 (voice), or
• 711 (relay)
The deadline for submitting applications is March 28, 2022.
Description of Outreach
The City Manager’s office posted a request for applications for the CCPD board on the city web site and
via a news release on February 24, 2022, with a closing date of March 28, 2022. During that time CCPD
sent the notice out to its electronic newsletter recipients (about 1,000 e-mail addresses), contacted the
Council on Aging and the DHSP Inclusion Services Program for possible candidates and reached out to
anyone who had inquired about board openings since the last application period in 2019. They also
utilized the city’s social media to recruit applicants.
Summary of Applications, Screening and Interview Process
Six individuals applied for these positions. One applicant provided no supporting materials and did not
respond to attempts to contact them. An interview team consisting of CCPD staff and three members of
the board conducted virtual interviews with each of the remaining five candidates. All applicants
identified as people with disabilities. The team agreed on two candidates to recommend for appointment.
As noted above, a third vacancy has opened on the board. A process will begin shortly to recruit
candidates to fill that vacancy.

About the Recommended Appointees

Packet Pg. 96

1.2

Candidate Keisha Greaves is an entrepreneur and advocate. She is the founder and owner of Girls
Chronically Rock, a Cambridge-based small business serving women with disabilities and chronic
illnesses. Robert Goss is an artist with personal and professional disability experience.
With your approval, we look forward to working with both of them.

PLANNING BOARD
CITY HALL ANNEX, 344 BROADWAY, CAMBRIDGE, MA 02139

Date:

November 2, 2022

Subject:

Incentive Zoning Rate Study Petition

Recommendation:

The Planning Board recommends ADOPTION, with clarifying
changes.

To the Honorable, the City Council,
On October 18, 2022
a public hearing to discuss a
Zoning Petition
i
by the City Council
to amend Paragraph (d) of
Section 11.202
of the Zoning Ordinance of the City of
Cambridge.
The City shall initiate a reevaluation of the
Housing Contribution Rate and any other aspect of these Incentive Zoning Provisions at an
interval of no less than three (3) years from the time of the previous reevaluation. Under current

City Councillor Quinton Zondervan explained the purpose of the Petition. The Planning Board
also received a memo from
in advance.
Board members asked questions of Councillor Zondervan and CDD staff, and discussed the
merits of the Petition. No members of the public offered comments. At the conclusion of the first
hearing, the Board voted to send a positive recommendation.
Board members were generally supportive of the proposal. Members noted that the affordable
housing crisis is acute, and it is important to get up-to-date information on a regular basis. Board
members also noted that it provides the City Council with options on when to initiate a study but
is not prescriptive.
For clarity, Board members recommended that
amended to be more specific. The CDD memo suggests
reevaluation was received by the City Council

be

The Planning Board voted with seven members in favor of transmitting the above report. One
member was absent.
Respectfully submitted for the Planning Board,

Catherine Preston Connolly, Chair.

CITY OF CAMBRIDGE, MASSACHUSETTS

Page 1 of 1
Packet Pg. 102

1.5

CMA 2022 #215
IN CITY COUNCIL
November 7, 2022
I am herby requesting an appropriation in the amount of $600,000 from Free Cash to the Public
Investment Fund Human Service Programs Extraordinary Expenditures account, to support softball field
improvements at Danehy Park.
The funds are required to improve the field conditions in time for the 2023 spring softball season. The
improvements will include, but are not necessarily limited to: painted fence posts and new fence fabric,
backstop and team area windscreens, replacing the Field 1 infield, regrading infield lips and depressions,
new team benches, new bleachers and trash receptacles.
In June of 2022, Cambridge Recreation met with representation from Girls Youth Softball to walk though
Danehy Park, the primary home of Girls Youth Softball, to review facilities and playing conditions. This
inspired a series of additional conversations to collect recommendations to improve softball fields in
Cambridge. On September 7th the recommendations were reviewed by a focus group that will continue to
support the needs and interests of Girls Youth Softball moving forward. The group consists of current and
former players, coaches, Girls Youth Sports leadership and City Staff.
Cambridge Recreation and Department of Public Works (DPW) staff categorized the recommendations
into short-term and longer-term projects. This appropriation will address improvements that can be made
in time for the 2023 spring softball season. Cambridge Recreation staff will continue to work with the
Board of Girls Youth Softball to review the recommendations that would require more structural fixes
and take longer to implement. That work will include continued conversations with Girls Youth Softball
about the use of softball fields in other neighborhoods.

Packet Pg. 103

1.6

CMA 2022 #216
IN CITY COUNCIL
November 7, 2022
I am hereby requesting the appropriation of the Adult and Community Learning Services grant
received from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE) in
the amount of $6,000.00 to the Grant Fund Human Service Programs Salary and Wages account.
This additional appropriation increases the initial Adult and Community Learning Services grant
received from the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education (DESE)
to $1,276,049.00 and will be used to pay for a portion of teachers’ salaries to participate in The
Standards That Matter (TSTM) Train the Trainer Academies. TSTM is a DESE curriculum
project.

Packet Pg. 107

1.10

CMA 2022 #220
IN CITY COUNCIL
November 7, 2022
I am hereby requesting the appropriation of the Massachusetts Housing and Shelter Alliance grant funded
by the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) in the amount of $103,339.03 to
the Grant Fund Human Service Programs Salary and Wages account ($68,889.03), and to the Grant Fund
Human Service Programs Other Ordinary Maintenance account ($34,450.00).
Funds will be used for costs related to the Carey Men’s Permanent Supported Housing Program operated
by the Multi-Service Center. This program assists homeless men to end their homelessness through
providing housing at the Cambridge YMCA and counseling and case management services. Carey
Program participants are assisted with issues that may have prevented them from maintaining stable
housing, such as substance abuse, legal issues, mental health challenges, employability and more. Funds
will be allocated for staff at the Multi Service Center, contracted participant services and supplies.

for construction projects and gained insights into what is involved in these fields.

Packet Pg. 111

2.1

City of Cambridge

O-3
Calendar Item # 1
FIRST IN COUNCIL
October 17, 2022
November 7, 2022

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS
COUNCILLOR TONER
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN
COUNCILLOR AZEEM
WHEREAS:

In recent years, the City has worked to address a number of different, critical issues
that impact the wellbeing of our community and our planet via a number of different
policies and initiatives that are tied to the development of new commercial and
residential buildings; and

WHEREAS:

From increasing the linkage fees that developers must pay into the Affordable Housing
Trust Fund, to increasing the mandatory amount of inclusionary units in new
residential buildings of ten units or more, to our Net Zero policies, to the proposed
BEUDO amendments, to the Affordable Housing Overlay, to the possibility of
eliminating parking minimums, there have been a number of new or refreshed
initiatives enacted by the City over the past half decade; and

WHEREAS:

While each of these policies addresses a very real need, it would be prudent for the
City to take a moment to request that an analysis be conducted to determine what
impact, if any, all of these combined policies have had upon local commercial and
residential development, and what impact may yet be felt by these combined policies
in the near term, before the City looks to enact further policies or initiatives related to
development; now therefore be it

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to direct the Community
Development Department to provide a comprehensive list of current Cambridge
policies that impact the cost of local commercial and residential development and those
that are known to be in the pipeline, to note whether similar policies exist in the
neighboring cities of Boston and Somerville, and to report back to the City Council on
this matter in a timely manner.
In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by a yea and nay vote:Yeas 9; Nays 0; Absent 0.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Taylor, Bernice
From:

Adriana M. <amessina122@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 12:13 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
Clerk; info@cambridgebikesafety.org
Brattle St. Bike Lanes - Overcoming the Delay & Temporary Protected Lanes

Hello!
I first want to say thank you for implementing the Garden St. lanes, and for the upcoming protected bike lanes on River
St. and Hampshire St.. They will be invaluable for the safety of our Boston and Cambridge bikers.
However, I am disappointed to hear of the delays on the Brattle St. bike lanes. Having a multiple-month delay to people
riding bikes on this stretch will be hugely damaging and dangerous to those who regularly commute on Brattle St.
Myself and many other bikes ask that the city proceed with the project as immediately as possible, using temporary
barriers until the permanent concrete barriers can be installed. In fact, the use of temporary traffic control devices is
acceptable within the historic district with no further approval needed. So there is no reason to delay this safety
measure further.
Thank you,
Adriana Messina

Attachment: Adriana Messina Brattle St. Bike Lanes - Overcoming the Delay Temporary Protected Lanes (COM 847 #2022 : A communication

3.1.a

1

Packet Pg. 116

3.2.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Keyssar, Alex <Alex_Keyssar@hks.harvard.edu>
Friday, October 28, 2022 3:13 PM
City Council; City Clerk; City Manager
Garden St one way

I share the views of my neighbors who are extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to
be converted to one-way despite our petition appealing the Traffic Director’s decision. According to
the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board hears our appeal and reaches a
decision. It is unclear how the city could reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its own
laws.
As someone who drives west on Garden Street on a daily basis, I will find the one-way plan to be
disruptive; it will also mean that to take alternative routes I will spend an extra ten minutes a day with
my car idling in traffic on Mass Ave or Concord/Huron Aves. If we are trying to reduce vehicle
emissions, that doesn’t sound like a great plan.
Alexander Keyssar
Mt. Vernon St., Cambridge

Attachment: Alexander Keyssar Garden St one way (COM 848 #2022 : A communication was received from Alexander Keyssar)

Taylor, Bernice

1

Packet Pg. 117

Taylor, Bernice
From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Anna Bensted <alibensted@gmail.com>
Sunday, October 30, 2022 12:58 PM
City Manager
City Council; City Clerk
Garden Street petition

Dear City Manager,
We can only regard your your decision to allow Garden St. to be converted to one-way despite our petition appealing the
Traffic Director’s decision as a serious problem on two fronts.
According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board hears our appeal and reaches a decision, so it is
unclear how the city could reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its own laws.
So not only do we now see a real change for the worse in the traffic in our street, but our faith in the integrity of a system
that is meant to allow for the input of residents and taxpayers has suffered a serious blow.
We write this not only as local residents, but as keen cyclists who see absolutely no benefit to the change.
All those who have previously walked, cycled and accompanied young children and elderly relatives up and down the side
streets of Garden will now lose out on doing those activities with any sense of safety.
Sincerely,
Alison Anna Bensted
Lino Pertile
18 Walker Street
Cambridge

Attachment: Alison Anna Bensted and Lino Pertile Garden Street petition (COM 849 #2022 : A communication was received from Alison Anna

3.4.a

From:

Anjali Merchant <anjiemerchant@gmail.com>

Cambridge Bicycle Safety; Clerk
yhuang@cambridgema.gov, council@cambridgema.gov, ooriordan@cambridgema.gov,

Hi there,
I wanted to say thanks for the new protected bike lanes on Garden Street, and for the upcoming lanes on River St. and Hampshire St. I use
my bike to get around Cambridge and I appreciate the Council's support for these lanes and the hard work of everyone on staff to make
them happen.
I have heard that the Brattle St. protected lanes will be delayed until the spring. A delay of 6 months significantly increases the risk of
preventable injuries, especially with the impending winter and shorter daytime hours. I ask that the city proceed with the project
immediately using temporary barriers until the concrete barriers can be installed. I know that temporary traffic control devices are
acceptable within the historic district with no further approval needed.
Thank so much,
Anjali Merchant

Great letter, Marie!
Let's hope common sense prevails and that particular Councilor be prevented from participating in any discussions
based on her prior behavior and obvious bias on this matter. As is obvious to anyone living in this City, East Cambridge
has been subjected to the intrusion of more developers in our neighborhood than has any other area in the City, and

Sent from Yahoo Mail on Android
On Tue, Oct 25, 2022 at 7:11 AM, marie saccoccio
<saccocciom@yahoo.com> wrote:

Dear Madam Clerk:
Could you kindly include this letter and attachments to Neighborhood & Long Term Planning,
Public Facilities, Arts & Celebration Committee in opposition to Petition to Amend the
Conservation District Ordinance? I submitted this over a year ago. I will not be available to
speak at the meeting today. My submission below is precisely what I offered last year.

Dear Council Members and City Manager:

As many of you know, I am fourth generation Cambridge resident. My family has paid
taxes to this city for over a century. My parents and grandparents worked in the factories here. I
say this to emphasize my breath of interest in preservation of our history, whether it be our
immigrant industrial history; our African American history; or, yes, even the history of our
privileged West Cambridge landed gentry. Based on this appreciation and full well having
experienced the razing of Boston's West End, along with the unbridled development in

Attachment: Audrey Cunningham Re Fwd Letter in response to Amendment to Chapter 2.78 entitled Historical Buildings and Landmarks.

Taylor, Bernice

1

Packet Pg. 120

Kendall, I rallied some neighbors to study the possibility of establishing a Conservation District
in East Cambridge. We were not a group of old white privileged wealthy people. We were a
group of serious-minded residents who were truly motivated by an appreciation of the value in
our history and architecture. We met almost weekly for about 9 months in the St. Francis of
Assisi Church Hall, a notable Landmark itself. We spent much time establishing boundaries,
looking at other guidelines employed around the country and within Cambridge, taking walking
tours of the boundaries; and researching the history of this great neighborhood.

Once the petition for establishing a Conservation District was filed we were pilloried all
over social media. Audrey Vetrano Cunningham and I were mocked incessantly with video clips
posted to twitter even ridiculing our "Italian accents." Bill Dines was portrayed as an out of
control privileged old white man. John Whisnant was mercilessly described as an old greedy
white man. Truly the basis was absurd since the positions we were taking were absolutely
supported in law. Our MGL c. 40(C) provides standing to owners. It is the law. There is no
value judgement we were making. It is the law.
Recently I note that Conservation Districts in Brookline have been struck down as
unlawful. Why?? Because they did not mirror the process or requirements set forth in MGL. C.
40(C). Our Conservation District ordinance and process up to now is absolutely faithful to
40(C). The Citizen Petition now presented as a Proposed Ordinance, masquerading as Policy
Order 35, is devoid of any foundation in law to be presented as a variation of any Conservation
District composition or process. The Policy Order creates some kind of land use system, not
zoning and not preservation, premised on equity and diversity and business interests. It
completely alters the rigors of standing which are as old as property law itself and
violates 40C. It rejects any notion of professional or academic qualifications likewise in
violation of 40C. And in doing so, this proposal insults the lawyers, architects, real estate
professionals, urban planners and historians who have always comprised the Commission and
the Neighborhood Conservation Districts and most have been uncompensated volunteers.
I am attaching here two cases for your review and suggest that the City Solicitor be
contacted before the Council descends further down this road. The Brookline case clearly
provides that even with a Neighborhood Conservation District, the strictures of MGL c. 40C
apply. You simply cannot ignore state law. And, I am attaching here a Cambridge case
involving our Avon Hill Neighborhood Conservation District in which the Superior Court found
that :

“The Commission incorrectly argues for a "supported by substantial evidence" standard.
Cambridge Municipal Code, 2.78.240 ("The superior court may reverse a determination if
it is not supported by substantial evidence in the record"). To the extent such section of the
Municipal Code seeks to alter the statutory standard of review as set out in G.L.c. 40C,
§12A, such section violates state supremacy, and is therefore void.”

I also note that in violation of Plan E, one City Councilor intervened with the Cambridge
Historic Commission, personally attempting to stop the process and promote her constituents’
position. I have a letter she authored attesting to this and there is also a recorded meeting of the
Conservation District in which she demanded that the entire process be stopped. As this is a

Attachment: Audrey Cunningham Re Fwd Letter in response to Amendment to Chapter 2.78 entitled Historical Buildings and Landmarks.

3.5.a

2

Packet Pg. 121

3.5.a

I am attaching here a wonderful resource compiled on the history of preservation in this
Commonwealth. It is not a tool we suddenly discovered so as to become rich overnight. I also
note that our Historic Commission, and especially the Neighborhood Conservation Districts, are
often cited nationally as a kind of gold standard.

Respectfully submitted,

Marie Elena Saccoccio, Esquire
55 Otis Street
Cambridge, MA 02141

Dear Cambridge City Manager Yi-an Huang,
First, congratulations on your new position.
Second, I am surprised and disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to
be converted to one way despite the Cambridge residents' petition appealing
the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be
suspended until the Traffic Board hears an appeal and reaches a decision.
Please explain why you and the City have proceeded in violation of the City's
own laws. Thank you.
Awaiting your response,
Ausra Kubilius, resident at 21 Cogswell Ave for 31 years

Dear City Manager,

request an appeal of the Traffic Department’s decision. According to the city’s own ordinance/law, all work should be

violation of its own laws is a mystery.
Beth Gamse

Shocked at the City's decision to allow Garden St conversion to one-way despite a
petition appealing the Traffic Director’s decision.

Dear City Manager,
I am both shocked and extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to be converted to one-way despite
our petition appealing the Traffic Director’s decision.
According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board hears our appeal and reaches a decision. It is
unclear how the City could reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its own laws.
What type of autocratic, anti-democratic City has Cambridge become that would allow this to take place?
Where was the urgency to disregard the concerns of residents and the short-circuiting of the legal process?
It makes no sense at all.
Thank you.
Sincerely,
Bob von Rekowsky
45 Brewster Street

From:

carol.weinhaus@outlook.com
Friday, October 28, 2022 1:14 PM
City Manager; City Council; City Council; City Clerk
Extremely disappointed with traffic and parking changes

Dear City Manager and Cambridge City Council,
I am extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to be converted to one-way despite the petition
appealing the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board hears
our appeal and reaches a decision. It is unclear how the city could reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its
own laws.
I am also extremely disappointed with the lack of City Council support for neighborhood considerations regarding traffic
and parking. In addition to Garden Street, the treatment of Massachusetts Avenue by the Porter Square area and the
loss of parking that is the life-blood of the small stores is another example. The focus on bikes alone, fails to look at the
reality of people who can’t ride a bike, the icy/snowy winters, the ongoing failure to the MBTA to provide viable
alternative service to cars, the problems for first responders’ close access to properties (Cambridge Hospital is one
example), and the continuation of bike riders on sidewalks, even with the bike lanes.
In next year’s election, I will only support and vote for City Council candidates that represent neighborhood and small
business owner concerns.
Carol
Carol Weinhaus
271 Concord Avenue
Cambridge, MA 02138

Attachment: Carol Weinhaus Extremely disappointed with traffic and parking changes (COM 855 #2022 : A communication was received from

3.9.a

1

Packet Pg. 127

Taylor, Bernice
From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

carol.weinhaus@outlook.com
Friday, October 28, 2022 7:20 PM
publicengagement@mbta.com
City Council; City Clerk; City Council; 'Jehlen, Patricia (SEN)'; Rep. Marjorie Decker
Stop the changes to bus routes in west Cambridge (routes 74, 75, 78, & 72)

Dear MBTA,
I am a senior, have no car, and use public transportation. Your proposed cuts to the MBTA bus service in west
Cambridge (routes 74, 75, 78) and the loss of route 72 mean that transit is difficult, or even unavailable (especially on
nights and weekends). The nearest MBTA subway stations are a mile or more away. In winter, the long wait, or even
lack of service makes it difficult to reach necessary destinations. In addition to the weather, for many people, bikes are
not an option.
Currently, the City of Cambridge is building a large elementary school on Vassal Lane, which is a block away from these
routes. Also, the City is removing parking spaces from nearby Garden Street. The result of the City’s actions is that
public transportation is needed even more. And even a minor change makes a major change for the worse for those of
us that don’t have a car.
The letter by Charles Bahne in Cambridge Day, “Proposed bus cuts will make transit unusable”, points out many of the
issues https://www.cambridgeday.com/2022/07/27/proposed-bus-cuts-will-make-transit-unusable/. As the article
states:
“This is the only transit available for a neighborhood that has many medical offices as well as a regional Social Security
office. In addition, much new development has been built and proposed here. Instead of transit-oriented development,
we’ll build the development, then remove the transit!”
A former City councilor, Jan Devereux, made this comment to the Cambridge Day letter:
“The proposed reductions in service will, as you say, make the bus impractical as an alternative to driving. Some people
may say that our area isn’t high need or dense enough to be prioritized for transit service, but they ignore the many
destinations along Concord Ave the bus serves: affordable and senior housing, two nursing homes, medical buildings,
shopping, the existing (and planned future) dense housing and workplaces in the Quad, Danehy Park and Fresh Pond.
This is shortsighted, to say the least, and feels punitive and pointless.”
Please stop the proposed changes to the west Cambridge routes. Instead, given the City of Cambridge’s current actions,
bus service should be increased on these routes.
Sincerely,
Carol Weinhaus
Concord Avenue
Cambridge, MA

Attachment: Carol Weinhaus Stop the changes to bus routes in west Cambridge (routes 74 75 78 72) (COM 856 #2022 : A communication was

Chris Willard <cwillard@gmail.com>
Friday, October 28, 2022 5:30 PM
City Manager; City Clerk; City Council
Biker unhappy with garden changes

Hi,
I'm a regular cyclist, driver and MBTA user, and I vote!
I've appreciated some of the bike lanes changes on Mass Ave, but have to say the garden changes see absolutely insanetraffic today on Concord was crazy, and I cant imagine how many schoolbuses are going to be belching diesel and noise
out onto side streets, all for bike lanes on a street that I already find very safe to ride on.
Meanwhile, parking at the church on garden, where I drop my kids for preschool and have friends who attend AA
meetings, will be severely impacted, in addition to other church services, more people will be circling around looking for
parking ,adding more fumes, noise, frustration and traffic!
Meanwhile, my wife, who drops the kids at preschool and then jumps on the t, will now drive to and from preschool,
(doubling car and emissions time) to get on the bus that is cutting service on Concord to be in traffic again, to then take
the MBTA (and not drive) to get to work.
All of this before Vassal Lane school construction is completed!
Again, we all want well designed bike lanes, espcially as a regular cyclist. But I dont have space to store a cargo bike in
my apartment to take my kids to school, espeically in January!
Thanks for your consideration.
Chris
-cwillard@gmail.com
617/909/7640

Taylor, Bernice
From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

William Franks <franks@mit.edu>
Monday, October 31, 2022 11:52 AM
Huang, Yi-An
Clerk; info@cambridgebikesafety.org
Fwd: TAKE ACTION: Stop the delay of Brattle St. protected bike lanes

I support the installation of temporary barriers until the concrete ones arrive. The city’s mistake shouldn’t put lives at
risk.
Cole Franks
Inicio del mensaje reenviado:
De: Cambridge Bicycle Safety <info@cambridgebikesafety.org>
Fecha: 31 de octubre de 2022, 8:44:24 a.m. PDT
Para: cole.franks215@gmail.com
Asunto: TAKE ACTION: Stop the delay of Brattle St. protected bike lanes
Responder-Para: info@cambridgebikesafety.org

Hello bike friends,
While the Garden St. protected bike lanes are currently in the process of being installed, the
City of Cambridge wants to delay the initial Brattle St. protected bike lanes until the
spring, since they can’t get the necessary concrete barriers delivered in time.
This is not acceptable:
1. The delay was preventable. The last public meeting about the new project was
August 8th, but the supplies were only put out for bid on Sep 29th, almost two months
later, with bids due by Oct. 13th. The high-level design was already clear by that
point, so the City could have requested bids much earlier.
2. A delay of 6 months significantly increases the risk of preventable injuries.
Delays of even a few days can lead to more crashes: in both the Garden St. and
Porter Square projects, drivers hit cyclists just a handful of days before the new bike
lanes were installed. Leaving Brattle St. in its current state for many months
compounds the risk.

Attachment: Cole Franks Fwd TAKE ACTION Stop the delay of Brattle St. protected bike lanes (COM 859 #2022 : A communication was received

3.13.a

1

Packet Pg. 131

What we want:
1. In the long term, the City should plan better and order supplies earlier.
2. For now, the City should install the bike lanes anyway, and put in temporary
barriers until it’s possible to install the final concrete barriers. While the City
can’t fully implement the final design, they do have the ability to put down the final
street markings for the bike lanes, and then use temporary cones, barrels, or other
barriers until the concrete barriers are available.

How you can help:
Write to yhuang@cambridgema.gov, council@cambridgema.gov,
ooriordan@cambridgema.gov, bmckenna@cambridgema.gov, and CC
info@cambridgebikesafety.org so we can keep track.
(You can additionally CC clerk@cambridgema.gov to make sure your email appears in the
public record for next week’s council meeting.)
Just a quick two sentence email is perfect!

Talking points:
•

Thank City staff for implementing the Garden St. lanes, and for the upcoming
protected bike lanes on River St. and Hampshire St..

•

Point out the risks of a multiple-month delay to people riding bikes on this stretch;
share your personal experience if relevant.

•

Ask that the city proceed with the project immediately, using temporary barriers until
the concrete barriers can be installed.

•

Note that use of temporary traffic control devices is acceptable within the historic
district with no further approval needed.

Attachment: Cole Franks Fwd TAKE ACTION Stop the delay of Brattle St. protected bike lanes (COM 859 #2022 : A communication was received

From:

Subject:

Graeme Peel <greemp@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 2:30 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
info@cambridgebikesafety.org; Clerk
Brattle Street Protected Cycle Lane Delays - temporary measures

Dear Councillors,
As a resident of Cambridge, I would like to thank you for the work done to protect vulnerable users of Garden Street. I
was, however, very disappointed to hear about the 6 month delay on the Brattle Street project. This delay will endanger
many lives of vulnerable road users, especially as we move into the winter months. I ask that the city proceed
immediately with temporary measures to protect vulnerable road users on Brattle Street - put down the final street
markings for the bike lanes, and then use temporary cones, barrels, or other barriers until the concrete barriers are
available.
I remind councillors that the use of temporary traffic control devices is acceptable within the historic district with no
further approval needed. The city has a responsibility here to ensure that all measures are taken to protect lives. I
further remind you that just a few weeks before the Garden Street improvements, an 8 month pregnant woman was hit
by a left turning driver at the junction with Linnaean Street. Any delays to cycle lane projects are extremely dangerous
and all efforts must be made to put stop-gap measures in place until a more permanent protection can be offered.
Yours Sincerely,
Graeme Peel

Attachment: Graeme Peel Brattle Street Protected Cycle Lane Delays - temporary measures (COM 863 #2022 : A communication was received

Joan Pickett <jpickett7@yahoo.com>
Saturday, October 29, 2022 12:06 PM
City Manager; Glowa, Nancy
City Clerk; City Council
Garden St

Dear City Manager,
I am extremely disappointed by the decision to proceed with the one way conversion of Garden St.
According to city regulations, the project should have been suspended once the petition was filed and
citizens given the right to a timely appeal.
Converting this major thoroughfare to one way is not a trivial decision.The decision for one way traffic
flow was not part of the CSO (which did mandate the installation of separated bike lanes on Garden
St.) The CSO left the implementation and decision on street design up to the Traffic Director. I think
this important detail, on which the citizen's petition was based, should have been sufficient for the city
solicitor to recommend suspending the project.
Joan Pickett
59 Ellery Street

City Manager
City Council; City Clerk
Proceeding with Garden St conversion

Dear City Manager + Council:
I am extremely disappointed with your decision to move ahead with the garden street modifications despite the fact
that two petitions to have the traffic board review the plans have been acknowledged. It is not clear to me, from either
a political or financial perspective, why you would blatantly decide to ignore appropriate (by law) process here.
I would strongly urge you to reconsider these modifications and to return them to their original state until the traffic
board has had the opportunity to review and provide input/feedback. I am concerned that your actions will lead to
escalation of a tenuous situation. In a charged election cycle, I should think that hearing all voices/perspectives - and
not just a minority interest group - would be best advised.
John Pena

Packet Pg. 146

3.27.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Kathryn Nassberg <kathryn.nassberg@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 1:53 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
info@cambridgebikesafety.org; Clerk
Bike safety

Dear Councilmembers,
I am writing to voice my objection to the protected bike lanes on Brattle Street being delayed until the spring. As
someone who bikes on a regular basis and who was recently injured in a car-related bike accident that resulted in a
broken arm, I take bike safety very seriously. There needs to be more physical separation between bikes and motor
vehicles, and we cannot wait months until the concrete barriers are delivered. Even temporary measures such as cones
or barrels are better than nothing - there need to be clear markings to denote bike-specific lanes, and this will be
exceedingly important as we get into the winter months with the potential for restricted bike mobility on the street due
to snow. I ask that you please proceed with the project immediately using temporary barriers, especially as no further
approval would be needed.
There are enough people injured because of a lack of protected bike lanes (myself included) - the last thing we need is
another ghost bike planted at an intersection.
Sincerely,
Kathryn Nassberg
-Kathryn Nassberg
(570) 447-3200

protect your
privacy,

prevented
automatic
download of

from the

Kavish Gandhi <kmbrgandhi@gmail.com>
Friday, October 28, 2022 6:32 AM
City Council; City Manager; City Clerk
Public Comment, 10/31

Hi,
I'm writing to:
- Support Applications & Petitions #2
- Strongly support Applications and Petitions #3
- Support PO#5
All the best,
Kavish Gandhi

Garden St changes

Dear City Manager,
I am extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to be converted to one-way despite
our petition appealing the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be
suspended until the Traffic Board hears our appeal and reaches a decision. It is unclear how the City
could reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its own laws.
How is this democratic? Does the City administration not exist to serve the needs and interests of
ALL City residents or merely a few specific pressure groups? I and many others like me are disgusted
by this undemocratic decision – and the decisions that were made about Mass Ave regarding bike
lanes – all of which are worsening the quality of life for LONG-TERM residents and families in this
City. It will be reflected in my voting choices for Council going forward.
Sincerely,
Ken Beausang

Cambridge Traffic/Bike Lanes

City Council:
1. Your bike lane policies have destroyed the neighborhoods and rendered unsafe Harvard Square, Inman Square, and
now Garden Street, with no end to your ill-advised assault on common sense in sight.
2. You have been cowed by a small minority of residents in a headlong rush to appease a loud lobby at the expense of
the safety, and neighborhood integrity.
3. The unsightly, disorganized, congested, dysfunctional and hazardous conditions of our roads, sidewalks, parking
spaces and access to neighborhood businesses would be laughable were it not so patently offensive to the rights of a
majority of Cambridge residents.
4. I stand with those citizens who have been unheard and foreclosed from voicing unequivocal objection to the City’s
bike lane policies.

From:

Liz Walker <lizcwalker@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 12:03 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke; Clerk
Please install the Brattle St bike lanes now

Dear Councillors, City Manager, and City Staff,
I'm writing to ask that the city proceed with the Brattle Street bike lane installation immediately. I bike this stretch of
Brattle Street to and from work multiple times a day, and I have felt much less safe since the sharrows were
removed in preparation for the new bike lanes. I've actually been counting down the days until the new bike
lanes will be installed and ready for use!
So when I heard that there is a potential multiple-month delay due to concrete material delays, I was upset. I feel
very nervous about the dangerous current state of affairs continuing through the winter. Please put down the final
street markings for the bike lanes now, and use temporary cones, barrels, or other barriers until the concrete
barriers are available.
Thank you for approving these designs and for executing them as soon as possible!
Kind regards,
Liz Walker
242 Lexington Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

Attachment: Liz Walker Please install the Brattle St bike lanes now (COM 877 #2022 : A communication was received from Liz Walker)

Re: Garden Street Conversion to One-Way

Dear Sam and Frank Reese,
Many thanks and much appreciation for your plea to the City of Cambridge.
We often meet when you’re out walking with your adorable dogs and I now with my rollator. I too have enjoyed my
home on Walker Street, and am distressed by the traffic and circulation problems caused by this unfortunate
development.
I write now to thank you for your ‘legalistic’ appeal to the City of Cambridge, about the disruption of transport to and
from our homes, and the additional traffic on Walker Street caused by the unfortunate conversion of Garden Street to
one-way into the Common and Harvard Square. I add to those addressed in the City Gov the name of Stephen Meuse,
the Cambridge Project Manager. And I add copies of my earlier please to him, and his initial reply.
Thanks again for your reaction, and do please keep my name on the list, and especially if there are any possibilities of
reversal of this unfortunate development in our neighborhood.
Kind regards,
Pat Grimsted

2

Packet Pg. 158

<wlcondit@gmail.com>, Kathy Caple <kathycaple@gmail.com>, "Shelemay, Kay K."
<shelemay@fas.harvard.edu>, Adam Baratz <adam.baratz@gmail.com>, "Berkman, Lisa"
<lberkman@hsph.harvard.edu>, Dan Anderson <dan@andersonporter.com>, Janelle Fisher
<jsmartfisher@gmail.com>, "Singer, Judith D." <judith_singer@harvard.edu>, Eric Ward
<enw1776@yahoo.com>, Nan Soule <soulearama@hotmail.com>, Lisa Sebesta <lsebesta@gmail.com>,
"Patricia K. Grimsted" <grimsted@fas.harvard.edu>, Debby Pugatch Kernochan <dkernochan@gmail.com>,
Elizabeth Dempster <eodempster@post.harvard.edu>, Erik Sebesta <erik.sebesta@gmail.com>, Erin Dullea
<erindullea@hotmail.com>, Jan Emlen <janemlen@gmail.com>
Subject: Garden Street Conversion to One-Way

Dear City Manager,
I find it ironic that in a city as exceptionally well-managed as Cambridge, that the Garden Street
conversion to one-way has been such a botched project. Not only has it created a traffic flow
nightmare, the entire process is in violation of established law. In a city where citizens’ opinions have
historically been actively sought, our appeal has been ignored.
Over and above this compelling reason to reverse course is the adverse impact on the neighborhood.
Due to the ill-conceived one-way on Garden, the traffic department has converted a sleepy residential
street into a high speed thoroughfare. My wife and I are elderly, but active walkers of two small dogs.
Walker Street supports considerable pedestrian traffic, bicycles, small children heading to the nearby
elementary school, and Harvard students on scooters. Those with driveways must back out into the
street. For the 50 years we have lived here, it has always been a safe, quiet, and vehicle friendly
street. Suddenly it has become a perceived short-cut for irritated drivers trying to get through to
Massachusetts Avenue. Walker Street is no longer a safe place to travel.
To restate the obvious: My wife and I are surprised and discouraged by your decision to flaunt the law
and to allow Garden Street to be converted to one-way without due process. The Traffic Director’s
decision is unlawful and has created unanticipated consequences that must be remedied.
Thank you for your consideration of our concerns,
Sam and Frank Reece
45 Garden Street
Cambridge 02138

Attachment: Pat Grimsted Re Garden Street Conversion to One-Way (COM 883 #2022 : A communication was received from Pat Grimsted)

3.37.a

Packet Pg. 160

Taylor, Bernice
From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Meuse, Stephen <smeuse@cambridgema.gov>
Friday, August 5, 2022 10:05 AM
Grimsted, Patricia K.
RE: Garden Street Changes Hardly an Improvement for Walker Street Access

Hi Pat,
Options 2 and 3, that involve one way conversions of Garden Street, would impact some travel times to access Walker
Street depending on where you’re coming from, but our analysis is showing that it should be relatively minor. Of course
any increase in travel time can be considered a negative for many people and we understand that. We do have the 3
options under consideration still and we are asking for feedback about which would work best for the community. One
of those options does not impact access to Walker Street, though it does involve other tradeoffs.
The one-way conversion is not about one-way vs two-way bike lanes. Both can fit with two-way vehicle traffic (and no
parking). We looked at one-way options as a response to feedback from neighbors asking us to maintain as much
parking on Garden Street as possible, and in both one-way options, parking is increased along Garden Street in the
vicinity of Walker St.
When we have separated bike lanes, we also no longer need to post for street cleaning, as cars would no longer be
parked along the curb. Our sweepers would sweep the bike lane along the curb where the debris naturally accumulates
and people wouldn’t need to move their cars.
Hope this helps. Feel free to reach out again if you have any other questions or if you would like me to provide more
detail.
Regards.
-Stephen
Stephen Meuse, PE
Street Design Project Manager
Cambridge Traffic, Parking, and Transportation Department
344 Broadway, Cambridge, MA 02139
617-349-4713
Office hours:
M 8:30am-8pm
T, W, TH 8:30am-5pm
F 8:30am-noon

From: Grimsted, Patricia K. <grimsted@fas.harvard.edu>
Sent: Thursday, August 4, 2022 8:17 PM
To: Meuse, Stephen <smeuse@cambridgema.gov>
Subject: Garden Street Changes Hardly an Improvement for Walker Street Access
Dear Stephen Meuse,

Attachment: Pat Grimsted RE Garden Street Changes Hardly an Improvement for Walker Street Access (COM 883 #2022 : A communication was

3.37.c

1

Packet Pg. 161

As a now elderly longtime resident of Walker Street, who is still at the wheel, making Garden Street one way towards
the Square would be a SERIOUS INCONVENIENCE for access to Walker Street, as many would be coming most frequently
from Harvard Square.
Those who live on this street REALLY need easy access from both directions!
I can appreciate that cyclists may like a bike lanes on both sides of the street, but certainly I for one would strongly VETO
the one-way street suggestion for cars. I don’t know how other neighbors react to such a suggestion.
I’ll try to join the Community Meeting, if possible, but I hope that more of my Walker Street neighbors will speak up
about this plan. They will all be left with a good bit more extra driving and more frustration to reach their homes!
On street cleaning days, some Walker Street residents without off-street parking need to seek parking on Garden Street,
and what will happen to those possibilities?!?
Kind regards
Pat Grimsted

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Patrick W Barrett III <jbrealtyllc@gmail.com>
Sunday, October 30, 2022 6:01 PM
City Council
Tim Rowe; Daniel Sibor; City Clerk
North Mass Zoning Petition

Honorable Mayor and City Council,

A zoning petition for a small section of the North Mass Ave Overlay was submitted through me on behalf of
North Cambridge Partners. We hope that you will give it due consideration as it goes through the process of Planning
Board and Ordinance Committee review. The Mass Ave overlay was created in 1986 and has been amended five times
with the most recent amendments brought in 2012 which were designed to protect historical buildings, promote
outdoor seating, and to promote retail uses on the ground floor. Since those changes, the city has embarked on several
planning studies to try to spur housing development but very little has changed along this transit adjacent corridor. The
Envision study identified the main corridors of the city as areas where mixed use development, specifically with housing,
could and should be developed. The Cambridge St. study released, in part, last week showed heights and densities very
similar to the ones we are proposing, and we would argue that Mass Ave is an area where CDD’s proposed development
scheme is more likely to be realized. Since Monday night falls on Halloween and there is another likely to be much more
contentious petition before the Council, we will not be appearing to give public comment and offer this brief statement
in hope that staff may be able to get out of session earlier to be with their families and to enjoy the holiday. We look
forward to discussing this with the Council and are eager to hear your input.

Sincere Regards,

Patrick W. Barrett
Tim Rowe (North Cambridge Partners, LLC.)
Dan Sibor (North Cambridge Partners, LLC.)

Emails sent or received shall neither constitute acceptance of conducting transactions via electronic means nor shall
create a binding contract in the absence of a fully signed written contract.

Attachment: Patrick W. Barrett North Mass Zoning Petition (COM 886 #2022 : A communication was received from Patrick w. Barrett, Tim Rowe,

3.40.a

despite our petition appealing the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be

City Manager
City Council; City Clerk
conversion of Garden Street

To the City manager and council members:

Attachment: Phyllis Sonnenschein conversion of Garden Street (COM 888 #2022 : A communication was received from Phyllis Sonnenschein)

3.42.a

We in our neighborhood are greatly disturbed by the traffic director's decision regarding the
conversion of Garden St to a one way street. Not only does it pose significant difficulties of
getting in and out of neighborhoods around the square, but it is impossible to understand how
this conversion will increase the safety or flow of traffic. I predict problems ahead, accidents,
increased speeding and a number of unanticipated issues that negatively impact this wide
neighborhood (and city elections in the future).

1

Packet Pg. 167

According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board
hears our appeal and reaches a decision. It is unclear how the city could
reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its own laws.
How can our elected officials and consultants be so deaf to the efforts
of constituents to delay this process and follow the law. There is a lot of
anger around Cambridge in response to this action.
With dismay,
Phyllis Sonnenschein
19 Berkeley Street

GARDEN STREET - CAMBRIDGE

Dear City Manager,
We are extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to be converted to one-way despite our
petition appealing the Traffic Director's decision. According to the law, all work should be suspended until the
Traffic Board hears our appeal and reaches a decision. It is unclear how the city could reach the decision to
proceed in clear violation of its own laws.

City Manager; City Council; City Clerk; Carlone, Dennis; McKenna, Brooke; Simmons,
Denise; Mallon, Alanna; Toner, Paul; Azeem, Burhan; Baxter Patrick; Barr, Joseph; Wolfe,
Andreas; Riley, Kate; Watkins, Kathy; DePasquale, Louie; McGovern, Marc; Nolan, Patricia
Karen Davis; to: Andrew Liedtka; Jay Wickersham; Sue Miller; Michael Lauber; Britt
Wahlin; Carolyn Beeler; Ken Osgood; Dick Macnair; Alex Slive; Julia Schlozman; Rick
Sullo; Lewis Bushnell; Julie Kobick; Nadia Davila; Bruce Anderson; Jane Mansbridge;
Anna Bensted; Sarah Ward; Mary O'Meara; Miya Cain; Lino Pertile; Loray McDuffie;
Marion Boulicault; John Petrowsky; Kay Shelemay; Jessica Cheng; Joe Umphres; Emily
Rogal; George Soule; William Sawyer; Newbury, Lee; Joan Wickersham; Liz Robinson;

George Emlen; Joe Adiletta; Arthur Dempster; Ali Sullo; Natalie Bao Tram Le; Anne

Gamse; Larry Lesser; Kaela; Firey Cushman; Taylor Lowe; sam.reece02138@gmail.com;
Ellen Harkavy; steven seeche; Dylan Redor; Walter Condit; Kathy Caple; Jack Shelemay;
Adam Baratz; Lisa Berkman; Dan Anderson; Janelle Fisher; Judy Singer; Eric Ward; Nan
Soule; Lisa Sebesta; Pat Grimsted; Debby Pugatch Kernochan; Elizabeth Dempster; Erik
Sebesta; Erin Dullea; Jan Emlen
Garden Street Conversion to One-Way

Dear City Manager,
I find it ironic that in a city as exceptionally well-managed as Cambridge, that the Garden Street
conversion to one-way has been such a botched project. Not only has it created a traffic flow
nightmare, the entire process is in violation of established law. In a city where citizens’ opinions have
historically been actively sought, our appeal has been ignored.
Over and above this compelling reason to reverse course is the adverse impact on the neighborhood.
Due to the ill-conceived one-way on Garden, the traffic department has converted a sleepy residential
street into a high speed thoroughfare. My wife and I are elderly, but active walkers of two small dogs.
Walker Street supports considerable pedestrian traffic, bicycles, small children heading to the nearby
elementary school, and Harvard students on scooters. Those with driveways must back out into the
street. For the 50 years we have lived here, it has always been a safe, quiet, and vehicle friendly
street. Suddenly it has become a perceived short-cut for irritated drivers trying to get through to
Massachusetts Avenue. Walker Street is no longer a safe place to travel.

Attachment: Sam and Frank Reece Garden Street Conversion to One-Way (COM 891 #2022 : A communication was received from Sam and

Taylor, Bernice

1

Packet Pg. 173

To restate the obvious: My wife and I are surprised and discouraged by your decision to flaunt the law
and to allow Garden Street to be converted to one-way without due process. The Traffic Director’s
decision is unlawful and has created unanticipated consequences that must be remedied.
Thank you for your consideration of our concerns,
Sam and Frank Reece
45 Garden Street
Cambridge 02138

Garden Street Conversion to One-Way

Dear City Manager,
I find it ironic that in a city as exceptionally well-managed as Cambridge, that the Garden Street
conversion to one-way has been such a botched project. Not only has it created a traffic flow
nightmare, the entire process is in violation of established law. In a city where citizens’ opinions have
historically been actively sought, our appeal has been ignored.
Over and above this compelling reason to reverse course is the adverse impact on the neighborhood.
Due to the ill-conceived one-way on Garden, the traffic department has converted a sleepy residential
street into a high speed thoroughfare. My wife and I are elderly, but active walkers of two small dogs.
Walker Street supports considerable pedestrian traffic, bicycles, small children heading to the nearby
elementary school, and Harvard students on scooters. Those with driveways must back out into the
street. For the 50 years we have lived here, it has always been a safe, quiet, and vehicle friendly
street. Suddenly it has become a perceived short-cut for irritated drivers trying to get through to
Massachusetts Avenue. Walker Street is no longer a safe place to travel.
To restate the obvious: My wife and I are surprised and discouraged by your decision to flaunt the law
and to allow Garden Street to be converted to one-way without due process. The Traffic Director’s
decision is unlawful and has created unanticipated consequences that must be remedied.
Thank you for your consideration of our concerns,
Sam and Frank Reece
45 Garden Street
Cambridge 02138

Packet Pg. 175

3.47.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Sam Reece <sam.reece02138@gmail.com>
Saturday, October 29, 2022 4:13 PM
City Manager; Azeem, Burhan; Carlone, Dennis; Mallon, Alanna; McGovern, Marc; Nolan,
Patricia; Siddiqui, Sumbul; Simmons, Denise; Toner, Paul; Zondervan, Quinton
City Clerk
Garden St. petition

Dear Mr. Wang:
My husband and I have lived on Garden Street, at the corner of Walker St. for 46 years. We’ve
planted trees in our garden, raised kids and dogs and watched traffic and students go by. Now we
try to keep the Walker St. neighborhood a safe place to raise grandchildren. Thus, we are
extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St. to be converted to one-way between
Huron Ave and Arsenal Square, despite our petition appealing the Traffic Director’s
decision. According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board hears the
neighborhood's appeal and reaches a decision. It is unclear to us how the City could reach a
decision to proceed, in clear violation of its own laws. No work has been suspended at all.
Then there is the issue of why does the bicycle lobby get to choose what happens to traffic
circulation in our residential neighborhood? Bicyclists on Garden Street consist almost 100% of
Harvard students throughout the day. They can choose to get from their dorms, into the Square
on foot, by bicycle/electric scooter or bus. (By the way, electric scooters go about as fast as
cars!) Students have a place to park their “vehicles” safely and off the street, and they don’t pay
property taxes for these necessities! Oh, and by the way they don’t vote either!
Frustrated motorists trying to head North out of the Square, find they can’t access Mass Ave
from Concord Ave., then Bond St., then Garden St., so are bombing down Walker thinking it runs
thru to Mass. Ave. It doesn’t! They slam on the brakes, maneuver around the 90º turn at the
corner of Walker, and are faced with another stop sign at Shepard, but still no way to head North
on Garden.
And how about parking cars in the “middle” of Garden St. Is this a necessary
"improvement"? Why has parking been moved to the odd side of the street, after at least 46
years of being on the even side? And how’s parking in the middle of the street going to work
when it snows? I’ve learned that at least 34 parking spaces have been removed from Garden
St.. Those residents (and many are also taxpayers) will be vying for parking on the Garden side
streets. Good luck to us all!

Attachment: Sam Reece Garden St. petition (COM 893 #2022 : A communication was received from Sam Reece)

Taylor, Bernice

With great disappointment of the Cambridge City Council and Manager ...
1

Packet Pg. 176

Attachment: Sam Reece Garden St. petition (COM 893 #2022 : A communication was received from Sam Reece)

3.47.a

Sam Reece

-Sam Reece
sam.reece02138@gmail.com

Sheli Wortis <sheliwortis@comcast.net>
Monday, October 31, 2022 1:55 PM
City Council; Clerk
City Manager
regarding Cambridge Lab Regulation Zoning Amendment

I am proud to have been one of the signees of the citizens petition for the Cambridge Lab Regulation
Zoning Amendment (APP 2022 #53 on tonight’s City Council agenda) because it is time that the City
of Cambridge begin protecting our neighborhoods from both residential and small business
displacement. The scientific and pharmacological biotech industry has surrounded neighborhoods
that once were economically accessible to residents of limited and moderate means. Protecting the
areas identified in the amendment is one step policymakers can take to interrupt the affordability
crisis that has already severely affected the city.
Sheli Wortis
106 Berkshire St.
Cambridge, 02141

Attachment: Sheli Wortis regarding Cambridge Lab Regulation Zoning Amendment (COM 894 #2022 : A communication was received from

Taylor, Bernice

sima kainejad <skainejad@yahoo.com>
Sunday, October 30, 2022 12:41 PM
City Manager
City Council; City Clerk; Toner, Paul
Cambridge Streets for All

Dear city managers,
It is beyond my belief, having lived in this city for four decades, how certain decisions that should be public matters are
being made without taking the well-being of all its residents into consideration.
This type of behaviors on the city part has become now a pattern, and frankly sickening.
The Garden street being converted to a ONE WAY street is absolutely absurd and unwarranted. The inconvenience that
it will create, the traffic congestion, the confusion, and the list can go on.
These overnight, inconsiderate, ABRUPT decisions only indicate that the city is trying to please a certain minority
population, and scare away the rest; I would not be surprised if the city authorities succeed. We are at the verge of
having mental, emotional exhaustion by these type of decision markings.
This and some of the most recent city resolutions, which are not reflecting ALL the Cambridge residents’ wishes, will
be impacting my VOTES in a significant way, in the coming year!
Please do reconsider!
Best Regards,
Sima Kainejad, MA, LMHC
Psychotherapist

3.53.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Vickey Bestor <vickeybestor@gmail.com>
Sunday, October 30, 2022 3:46 PM
City Manager; City Council; City Clerk
Garden Street converstion

Dear City Manager Huang,
I am looking forward to the opportunity to meet you in person, unfortunately I cannot wait. I must
speak up now about the ongoing disaster that is inappropriately named the Cycling Safety Ordinance,
which neither promotes safer cycling nor produces safer streets as the proliferation of traffic accidents
on North Mass Ave has shown in the one year since the QB lanes were installed. The
CSO masquerades as a forward thinking, green initiative that is instead producing greater pollution
from traffic congestion and idling cars. Rather than increasing safety the CSO is producing more
traffic accidents while also marginalizing small businesses and hurting the majority of Cambridge’s
citizenry to advantage a tiny minority of cyclists, many of whom are merely commuters traveling
through our city.
Today, I write to join the many others who have written to express how profoundly disappointed we
are in your decision to allow Garden Street to be converted to one-way despite the petition appealing
the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic
Board hears the appeal and reaches a decision. How can the city proceed in clear violation of its own
laws? The changed traffic pattern on Garden will only increase congestion and pollution throughout
North and West Cambridge and further harm local residents.

We all realize that you are new to this job and clearly inherited this and other
problems. However, by your own statements in recent City Council Meetings you have both
acknowledged the existence of the Traffic Board and simultaneously ignored its mandate to promptly
(within 2 weeks) hold a hearing on the petitions from Brattle and Garden Streets that are before that
board.
We hope this problem can yet be resolved.
Sincerely,
Vickey Bestor
149 Upland Road

Attachment: Vickey Bestor Garden Street converstion (COM 899 #2022 : A communication was received from Vickey Bestor)

Taylor, Bernice

Tricia Carney <tcarney888@gmail.com>
Tuesday, November 1, 2022 2:40 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
Clerk; info@cambridebikesafety.org
Brattle Street projected bike lanes

Hello,
I am writing to thank the city of Cambridge for adding projected bike lanes. These are very important
infrastructure projects to implement. The bike lane projects like the Garden St. lanes, and for the upcoming
protected bike lanes on River St. and Hampshire St make a difference in people's lives. Protected bike lanes are
essential in the Cambridge area. Why? In the past month, I had the following happen to me:
•
•

a car swerved into an unprotected bike lane almost hitting me for no reason
a car honked at me continuously while I was biking on the side of the road. There was no space for the car
to pass me so the driver honked at me non-stop.

As an avid biker, I know firsthand that it is unsafe to bike beside automobiles on the Cambridge streets. Protected
bike lanes should be seen as crucial by the Cambridge council. Please proceed with temporary barriers on Brattle
Street. There are too many risks to delay implementing a protected bike path on Brattle Street. The use of
temporary traffic control devices is acceptable within the historic district with no further approval needed.

-Tricia Carney,
resident of Cambridge

Attachment: Tricia Carney Brattle Street projected bike lanes (COM 901 #2022 : A communication was received from Tricia Carney)

Perez, Lori

Re: Garden Street Conversion to One-Way

I join my fellow residents in writing to all city officials to express my concerns both for safety, legality, and due process
for the changes recently rushed through for Garden Street
I would expect that a city like Cambridge could do a much better job on all three
And it feels to me like those most affected were most disregarded while an ill conceived plan was quickly pushed
through to satisfy a poorly identified constituency along with some misguided notions of advancing bicycle use and
perhaps some vaguely articulated modest environmental benefit at the expense of the residents’ safety .
I urge you to re open the process of deliberation on this issue immediately to restore our faith in city government and
at a time when we worry about the efficacy of the workings of our democracy that you each demonstrate your
commitment to open deliberative process so that we can prudently consider restoring Garden Street to its former safer
plan
Respectfully submitted

Steven Seeche
1 Walker Street

Attachment: Steven Seeche Garden Street Conversion to One-Way (COM 902 #2022 : A communication was received from Steven Seeche)

1

Packet Pg. 186

Dear City Manager,
I find it ironic that in a city as exceptionally well-managed as Cambridge, that the Garden Street
conversion to one-way has been such a botched project. Not only has it created a traffic flow
nightmare, the entire process is in violation of established law. In a city where citizens’ opinions have
historically been actively sought, our appeal has been ignored.
Over and above this compelling reason to reverse course is the adverse impact on the neighborhood.
Due to the ill-conceived one-way on Garden, the traffic department has converted a sleepy residential
street into a high speed thoroughfare. My wife and I are elderly, but active walkers of two small dogs.
Walker Street supports considerable pedestrian traffic, bicycles, small children heading to the nearby
elementary school, and Harvard students on scooters. Those with driveways must back out into the
street. For the 50 years we have lived here, it has always been a safe, quiet, and vehicle friendly
street. Suddenly it has become a perceived short-cut for irritated drivers trying to get through to
Massachusetts Avenue. Walker Street is no longer a safe place to travel.
To restate the obvious: My wife and I are surprised and discouraged by your decision to flaunt the law
and to allow Garden Street to be converted to one-way without due process. The Traffic Director’s
decision is unlawful and has created unanticipated consequences that must be remedied.
Thank you for your consideration of our concerns,
Sam and Frank Reece
45 Garden Street
Cambridge 02138

Ruby A. <al2o3.ruby@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 6:36 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
info@cambridgebikesafety.org; Clerk
Install Brattle St. Bike Lanes Now

City Manager Huang, Commissioner O'Riordan, Assistant Director McKenna, and the Cambridge City Council:
First, thank you for implementing the Garden St. bike lanes, and for the upcoming protected bike lanes on
River St. and Hampshire St. I do not own a car so I bike everywhere - to and from work, to get groceries, and
just around Cambridge. Bike lanes, especially protected bike lanes, make my rides safer and more enjoyable.
The proposed 6 month delay in constructing protected bike lanes along Brattle street will, without a doubt,
allow for more crashes and cyclists getting hurt. This is something that must be mitigated.
I am asking you to proceed with the project immediately, using temporary barriers until the concrete barriers
can be installed. It should be noted that use of temporary traffic control devices is acceptable within the historic
district with no further approval needed, until the concrete barriers are delivered and installed.
Thank you,
Ruby A.

Attachment: Ruby A Install Brattle St. Bike Lanes Now (COM 903 #2022 : A communication was received from Ruby A)

Franklin Reece; Adam Baratz; Alex Slive; Ali Sullo; Anna Bensted; Anne Pierce; Aron

Re: Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion

Adding to your info Joe and Frank, an empty school bus went down Walker St around 5 pm yesterday. I'm pretty
confident that is not something we've seen before. Not sure how it navigated the corner.
Pete Robinson
