Attachment: Pete Robinson Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 904 #2022 : A communication was received from Pete Robinson)

Perez, Lori

1

Packet Pg. 189

On Wed, Nov 2, 2022 at 5:31 PM Joe Adiletta <adiletta@gmail.com> wrote:
Frank & Sam,
In support of this view, I am conducting my own traffic survey documenting the increase in volume. As it happens, an
elderly woman with a walker was making her way around the corner about 30 mins ago and almost got hit by a
truck! See the attached photo. You are correct, it’s just a matter of time. The tradeoff of cyclist safety for pedestrian
and child safety is unimaginable, really. Oh, by the way the majority of this traffic increase now drives right past
Graham & Parks elementary school!
The street was a route that was walked by many (Elizabeth Warren included), where our children played. No
longer. We will continue to seek recourse with the city. This was not only completely predictable but also avoidable.
Joe

Attachment: Pete Robinson Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 904 #2022 : A communication was received from Pete Robinson)

3.58.a

2

Packet Pg. 190

Attachment: Pete Robinson Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 904 #2022 : A communication was received from Pete Robinson)

3.58.a

3

Packet Pg. 191

3.58.a

Dear Yi-An Huang:
We appreciate your letter even though it does not address our concerns.
The fact that you consulted with the City Solicitor [Nancy Glowa] on the legality of moving forward with the
Garden Street changes would indicate that you were aware of the legal requirement for the Traffic Board to
hear our petition before implementing traffic changes. The appropriate and legal steps to have taken were
to 1) appoint three new members to the Board, 2) hear our petition, and then 3) determine how best to
move forward with the substantial changes to our neighborhood’s traffic patterns. There is little doubt that
your process has been backwards: 1) redirect traffic, 2) look at our petition, 3) recruit a new Board. Really?
Cambridge is perhaps the best run city in the Commonwealth, and you’ve approached this project
backwards.
Further, our letter to you of October 30th referred specifically to the increased traffic volume of both cars
and trucks, as well as the unacceptable vehicle speeds on Walker Street. Our safety has been compromised.
Someone is going to get hurt: A child, a dog walker, a bicyclist or scooterist, a pedestrian, it is just a matter
of time, and soon daylight savings will make conditions worse. Perhaps additional signage would help, or a
couple of speed bumps along Walker between Garden and Shepard? You’re the expert, and we need your
help on these issues.
Yes, the residents of Walker Street feel “unheard and frustrated”. Perhaps your next letter can remedy these
feelings as well as the issues that caused them.
Thank you,
Frank & Sam Reece
45 Garden Street

Attachment: Pete Robinson Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 904 #2022 : A communication was received from Pete Robinson)

On Wed, Nov 2, 2022 at 5:23 PM Franklin Reece <freece45@gmail.com> wrote:

4

Packet Pg. 192

3.59.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:

Subject:
Attachments:

Patrick W Barrett III <jbrealtyllc@gmail.com>
Wednesday, November 2, 2022 10:32 AM
City Council
City Clerk; Denise Jillson; Lee Farris; Robert Winters; Huang, Yi-An; Glowa, Nancy;
Joseph, Swaathi; Farooq, Iram; Michael Monestime; Kenneth Barron; Blier, Suzanne;
Carol O'Hare; Theodora Skeadas; Stuart Rothman; Michael Simon
RE: Lab Ban Petition Issue
lab regulation signature collection.xlsx

Honorable Mayor, City Manager, Cambridge City Council, Planning Board, and Ordinance Committee,
I refrained from coming in on Monday night to speak about the second coming of the lab ban primarily due to
the holiday but also in deference to people I'm working with to try to keep some semblance of "church and
state" in my work. I'm glad most people refrained and let staff be with family. I have a lot of questions and
hopefully the petitioners will be able to answer them, but in the committee where the first
attempt currently rests; not under the gun of a zoning petition. However, my biggest concern is centered on
one of the Ordinance Committee Chairs, Quinton Zondervan, who not only foreshadowed/threatened this
petition in open discussion during his first attempt to pass this exact language, but also included a link in his
newsletter dated October 7th, 2022 to contact Lee Farris encouraging people to sign it. Here is the link to
the Zondervan Newsletter and here is the concerning language:
"Unfortunately, the council decided to send this petition to a six-month study instead of sending
it to the Planning Board and Ordinance Committee for hearings immediately. I am deeply
concerned about the impact any delay in this conversation will have on our city. I recently
learned that a group of residents from across the city are taking up the torch and filing a citizens'
petition, which is automatically sent to the Planning Board and Ordinance Committee.
Please contact Lee Farris if you would like to sign the zoning petition."
While there is nothing "illegal" about what is being done here I think there is a compelling interest given
Zondervan's endorsement, and that his aide, omitted from this newsletter link, was also collecting signatures
with Farris (Spreadsheet of Signatures), significantly compromises Councilor Zondervan's ability to adjudicate
and possibly even vote on this petition language as it appears he is using his aide and Lee Farris as proxies for
his own agenda item currently in committee. At the bare minimum this raises some significant ethical
questions. I also think this might be a good time, since we are currently reviewing the charter, to include some
limiting language on what Council aides are allowed to do or more importantly; not do. I ask that
Zondervan recuse himself from voting on this petition and that he not be allowed to chair the
ordinance committee meetings on this either willingly or by order of the Mayor or City Manager in order
to preserve the integrity of the Ordinance Committee, Council, and to eliminate the perception that Zondervan
is using both his aide and a willing private citizen, who also claims leadership of her own political organization,
to put his thumb on the scales of process in this city.
Lastly, it shouldn't go unnoticed that once again Central Square is being put in the spotlight of further zoning
restrictions. We are about to come up on the nine year anniversary of the C2 planning study final
report. How incredibly sad is it that in the wake of all of these discussions on housing, labs, and development
we have wasted not only favorable market conditions but invaluable time, and in absence of that plan seen
very little growth or development in Central Square. Market Central and 907 Main are really the only examples
of C2-like development. With the expense of BEUDO, an excessive increase to linkage, and an inclusionary
zoning scheme that is absolutely broken I would be very interested to hear from the Council and Planning
Department how they imagine the future of Central Square. We learned in the 2019 Nexus Study that lab use

Attachment: Patrick W. Barrett III Lab Ban Petition Issue (COM 905 #2022 : A communication was received from Patrick W. Barrett III)

Perez, Lori

1

Packet Pg. 193

is really the only use that can "afford" to pay linkage. For those concerned about linkage amendments and
their impact ought to be even more concerned about what happens when you remove the source of those
payments. This conversation deserves time and consideration and attention to past work yet unfinished. If labs
are to be removed from a development plan for any square, what does the Council imagine will be built?
Housing? Central Square is largely built out and under private ownership and given how broken the current
inclusionary system is, that is highly doubtful. I would point out that the DHCD has not only recommended not
going above 10% for inclusionary zoning requirements, but they have made it legally impossible for
municipalities to go above 20%; as Cambridge did in 2015. (DHCD Guidelines) In the absence of any coherent
reasoning, the only other possibility is maybe this is yet another plan to stop development in Central Square
entirely? They have tried before. And again. Labs, or "Biotech" as Zondervan puts it in his letter, play a very
important role in our society, local economy, and shouldn't be removed from any plan to develop the city nor
our business districts; nuance is what is called for. Do we ban R&D from business districts? It will get
complicated. This conversation deserves time and consideration and attention to past work yet unfinished.
Please send this petition to ordinance quickly, vote it down, and let's make an honest
commitment to finishing what we started nine years ago.

Respectfully,
Patrick W. Barrett III
41 Pleasant St
CC: Planning Board
Ordinance Committee
Emails sent or received shall neither constitute acceptance of conducting transactions via electronic means nor
shall create a binding contract in the absence of a fully signed written contract.

3.60.a

Perez, Lori
Neil Goodwin <neilgoodwin@me.com>
Thursday, November 3, 2022 1:12 PM
City Clerk
Garden Street

Dear City Manager,
We are extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to be converted to one-way despite our
petition appealing the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be suspended until the
Traffic Board hears our appeal and reaches a decision. It is unclear how the city could reach the decision to
proceed in clear violation of its own laws.
Neil Goodwin
71 Washington Ave.
Cambridge 02140

Attachment: Neil Goodwin Garden Street (COM 906 #2022 : A communication was received from Neil Goodwin)

Michael Copacino <mhcopa@gmail.com>
Wednesday, November 2, 2022 11:05 AM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; McKenna, Brooke
Clerk; info@cambridgebikesafety.org
Garden Street bike Lanes

Dear City Staff,
Thank you for implementing bike lanes on Garden St. and the upcoming River St. and Hampshire Street projects.
However I heard there may be a delay in ordering supplies. A months long delay to can risk lives of cyclist and
increase traffic as it forces people into cars. I request we use temporary barriers while this is being resolved.
Thank you for your support!

Attachment: Michael Copacino Garden Street bike Lanes (COM 907 #2022 : A communication was received from Michael Copacino)

From:

Berkman, Lisa <lberkman@hsph.harvard.edu>
Thursday, November 3, 2022 8:43 AM
City Council; City Manager
City Clerk; Carlone, Dennis; McKenna, Brooke; Simmons, Denise; Mallon, Alanna; Toner,
Paul; Azeem, Burhan; Baxter Patrick; Barr, Joseph; Wolfe, Andreas; Riley, Kate; Watkins,
Kathy; DePasquale, Louie; McGovern, Marc; Nolan, Patricia; Karen Davis; to: Andrew
Liedtka; Jay Wickersham; Sue Miller; Michael Lauber; Britt Wahlin; Carolyn Beeler; Ken
Osgood; Dick Macnair; Alex Slive; Julia Schlozman; Rick Sullo; Lewis Bushnell; Julie
Kobick; Nadia Davila; Bruce Anderson; Mansbridge, Jenny; Anna Bensted; Sarah Ward;
Mary O'Meara; Miya Cain; Pertile, Lino; Loray McDuffie; Marion Boulicault; John
Petrowsky; Kay Shelemay; Jessica Cheng; Joe Umphres; Emily Rogal; George Soule;
William Sawyer; Newbury, Lee; Joan Wickersham; Liz Robinson; Maggie Baratz; Pete
Robinson; Elana Messer; Zoe Anderson; Katya Slive; Barry Wohl; Doug Elmendorf; Sabina
Islam; Jo Chaffee; Dara Cohen; Kate Clark; Aron Wander; George Emlen; Joe Adiletta;
Dempster, Arthur P.; Ali Sullo; Natalie Bao Tram Le; Anne Pierce; Douglas Bauer; Karen
Dynan; jean woodward; MB Flanders; Isaac Cheng; Beth Gamse; Larry Lesser; Kaela;
Cushman, Fiery Andrews; Taylor Lowe; sam.reece02138@gmail.com; Ellen Harkavy;
steven seeche; Redor, Dylan; Walter Condit; Kathy Caple; Shelemay, Kay K.; Adam Baratz;
Dan Anderson; Janelle Fisher; Singer, Judith D.; Eric Ward; Nan Soule; Lisa Sebesta;
Grimsted, Patricia K.; Debby Pugatch Kernochan; Elizabeth Dempster; Erik Sebesta; Erin
Dullea; Jan Emlen
Re: Garden Street Conversion to One-Way - a traffic disaster

Dear City Manager and all council members
You have ignored the voices of Cambridge residents. Without solid evidence of the
need for the change of traffic on Garden Street. This worsens the lives of many citizens
who walk and need to drive around town so essential to the vibrancy of Cambridge.

Not only has it created a traffic flow nightmare, the entire process is in violation of
established law. In a city where citizens’ opinions have historically been actively sought,
our appeal has been ignored.
Over and above this compelling reason to reverse course is the adverse impact on the
neighborhood. Due to the ill-conceived one-way on Garden, the traffic department has
converted a sleepy residential street into a high speed Those with driveways must back
out into the the street. Suddenly it has become a perceived short-cut for irritated drivers
trying to get through to Massachusetts Avenue. Walker Street is no longer a safe place
to travel. Garden street where my driveway is has become harder to back out of and

Attachment: Lisa Berkman Garden Street Conversion to One-Way - a traffic disaster (COM 908 #2022 : A communication was received from

Perez, Lori

1

Packet Pg. 202

drive into. Of this change were for the better I would not complain. However the
disadvantages of these traffic changes far outweigh any benefits.
To restate the obvious: We are surprised and discouraged by your decision to flaunt the
law and to allow Garden Street to be converted to one-way without due process. The
Traffic Director’s decision is unlawful and has created unanticipated consequences that
must be remedied.
Thank you for your consideration of our concerns,
Lisa Berkman 1 Walker street Cambridge

Attachment: Lisa Berkman Garden Street Conversion to One-Way - a traffic disaster (COM 908 #2022 : A communication was received from

3.62.a

2

Packet Pg. 203

Perez, Lori
From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Lee Farris <Lee@LeeFarris.net>
Monday, October 31, 2022 5:46 PM
City Council; Clerk
Lee Farris: comments supporting lab regulation zoning petition

[Please include these comments in the public record.]
Dear Mayor and Councilors,
I am one of the many signers of the Cambridge Lab Regulation Zoning petition.
This petition comes from over 250 people who are very concerned about lab expansion into the squares, and who don’t
think the conversation about what to do should be put off for another 6 months. The law gives residents the right to
submit a zoning petition at any time, and we are thoughtfully exercising this right. Over 250 signers is one of the largest
zoning efforts in recent memory. Signers include residents of below-market housing, market tenants, homeowners,
local businesses owners, and people from many different neighborhoods and groups.
The petition would prohibit new biotech lab construction in Cambridge's neighborhoods and squares, including Central,
Harvard, Porter, Inman, Cambridge Street, River Street, Concord Ave., Broadway, and more. Labs would continue to be
allowed in the Kendall Sq. area, the eastern part of Cambridgeport, and some parts of Alewife. The Alewife Overlay
Development Moratorium prohibits new lab development in Alewife Overlay Districts 1-5 until December 31,
2023. Future zoning in that area will be decided by a separate process that is already underway.
The petition proposes three zoning changes. It:
1. Defines the lab use, finally distinguishing it from other commercial uses. Similar but non-threatening uses like
dentist offices and academic research buildings are explicitly carved out.
2. Restricts new instances of lab use in vulnerable squares and zoned business districts.
3. Completely grandfathers all existing instances of the lab use within newly restricted areas.
I have seen estimates that lab development is around 3 times as profitable as market housing. Retail is also much less
profitable than labs.
I live near Central Sq. and am very concerned that lab development projects would crowd out housing and small retail. I
remember during the hearings on re-zoning Central Sq. for the Mass and Main project, the developer said the only
alternative to the proposed housing would be a lab building. I supported re-zoning Central Sq. to try to encourage more
housing. If labs are allowed, it will be harder to get housing.
When I asked residents to sign the petition, I found many residents were upset to learn that biotech labs were allowed
in some of these places.
I look forward to talking with councilors and city staff about where labs should and should not be allowed in our city.
Thanks for your consideration,

Attachment: Lee Farris Lee Farris comments supporting lab regulation zoning petition (COM 909 #2022 : A communication was received from

3.63.a

1

Packet Pg. 204

Lee Farris, President
Cambridge Residents Alliance: Working for a Livable, Affordable and Diverse Cambridge
https://www.cambridgeresidentsalliance.org/

3.63.a

Packet Pg. 205

3.64.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Cetrulo, Lawrence <LCetrulo@cetllp.com>
Tuesday, November 1, 2022 6:05 PM
City Manager
Carol Birnbaum; Adam Manacher; Heather Moulton; Kate Cetrulo; Shelagh Hadley;
Elizabeth Gilmore; Lynn Cetrulo; City Clerk; City Council
Re: Ignoring citizen’s rights

Dear Yi-An,
1. While we appreciate your reply to Mrs. Cetrulo’s email, it misses the salient point: The City has not implemented
improvements.
2. The City has replaced one problem which is correctable by strict enforcement of traffic laws (bicyclists who ignore
rules-of-the-road) with another harder-to-solve problem (creation of congested, unsafe, and unsightly side-street
issues).
3. In the short space of one week, the City has transformed Holly Ave. from a quiet, one lane, one block-long, residential
street, used primarily by residents, to a high speed cut-through for motorists seeking to avoid the congestion caused by
making Garden St. one-way.
4. In appeasing a vocal minority (bicyclists who generally do not own property on their routes of travel) you have
accomplished the dubious distinction of trammeling the rights of real estate tax-paying residents to the quiet enjoyment
of their property.
5. You have an impending crisis on Holly Ave. and elsewhere.
6. What are your plans to address the foreseeable consequences of your Garden St. decision?
Respectfully Submitted
Larry Cetrulo
46 Grozier Rd.
Lawrence G. Cetrulo
Cetrulo LLP
Two Seaport Lane
Boston, Ma

Perez, Lori

Thank you for your email. I appreciate your thoughts and your voice is important.
1

Packet Pg. 206

We recognize that implementing roadway improvements, including the installation of bike lanes pursuant to the Cycling
Safety Ordinance, has been difficult for our community. The City has undertaken significant efforts to develop options
that balance the imperative need to improve bicycle safety while mitigating disruptions to parking, traffic patterns, and
neighborhoods. This is not easy given the density of our streets. We have also put tremendous effort into community
engagement and acknowledge that many people still feel unheard and frustrated.
We will continue to strive for improvement on all fronts while navigating the challenges that face our community. Please
continue writing and engaging with the city!
Yi-An

Subject: Ignoring citizen’s rights
To All,
Once again the actual citizens who have some knowledge about issues in their neighborhoods have been ignored. I have
followed the lack of responsiveness to citizen’s concerns for years now. How a bike lobby and misguided information
and a lack of expertise on traffic patterns and safety could not be stopped from completely ruining Cambridge is beyond
me. I speak not just for my neigborhood but to name another the complete boggle that is Inman Square.
It is frightening to drive lest you hit a biker or pedestrian or other car at numerous intersections. Harvard Square is all
but ruined…yet we citizens are all but muzzled and ignored. Outrageous for people who think themselves representing a
future Cambridge…
Lynn Cetrulo

On Wed, Nov 2, 2022 at 5:23 PM Franklin Reece <freece45@gmail.com> wrote:

Dear Yi-An Huang:
We appreciate your letter even though it does not address our concerns.
The fact that you consulted with the City Solicitor [Nancy Glowa] on the
legality of moving forward with the Garden Street changes would indicate that
you were aware of the legal requirement for the Traffic Board to hear our
petition before implementing traffic changes. The appropriate and legal steps
to have taken were to 1) appoint three new members to the Board, 2) hear our
petition, and then 3) determine how best to move forward with the substantial
changes to our neighborhood’s traffic patterns. There is little doubt that your
process has been backwards: 1) redirect traffic, 2) look at our petition, 3)
recruit a new Board. Really? Cambridge is perhaps the best run city in the
Commonwealth, and you’ve approached this project backwards.
Further, our letter to you of October 30th referred specifically to the increased
traffic volume of both cars and trucks, as well as the unacceptable vehicle
speeds on Walker Street. Our safety has been compromised. Someone is going
to get hurt: A child, a dog walker, a bicyclist or scooterist, a pedestrian, it is just
a matter of time, and soon daylight savings will make conditions worse.
Perhaps additional signage would help, or a couple of speed bumps along
Walker between Garden and Shepard? You’re the expert, and we need your
help on these issues.
Yes, the residents of Walker Street feel “unheard and frustrated”. Perhaps
your next letter can remedy these feelings as well as the issues that caused
them.
Thank you,

Attachment: Larry Lesser Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 911 #2022 : A communication was received from Larry Lesser)

3

Packet Pg. 210

Perez, Lori
From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Kevin Moses <kmoses28@gmail.com>
Tuesday, November 1, 2022 10:38 AM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
Clerk
Delay of protected bike lanes on Brattle Street

To whom it may concern,
I was disappointed when I recently found out that the implementation of the protected cycle track on Brattle Street
would be delayed until next spring.
The Garden Street project has been an unmitigated success so far, and as someone who cycles from the west via Brattle
on a daily basis, I would love to have a more direct route that feels just as safe and comfortable.
As the creator of https://twitter.com/CambridgeCrash, I am acutely aware of the risks posed by delays to critical cycling
infrastructure. In fact, two crashes involving a cyclist and a pedestrian occurred in the week leading up to the Garden
Street implementation. I fear what injuries may occur if Brattle Street remains unfinished for 6 months.
Therefore, I am requesting that the department take whatever steps necessary to complete the project as soon as
possible. Even temporary separators would be a vast improvement while we await the precast concrete. I would also
like to point out that temporary traffic control devices do not require approval from the historical commission.
I look forward to hearing how the city will address these concerns soon.
Kevin Moses
West Cambridge Resident

Attachment: Kevin Moses Delay of protected bike lanes on Brattle Street (COM 912 #2022 : A communication was received from Kevin Moses)

3.66.a

1

Packet Pg. 211

3.67.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Shelemay, Kay K. <shelemay@fas.harvard.edu>
Thursday, November 3, 2022 11:42 AM
City Manager; CityCouncil@csmbridgema.gov; City Clerk; freece45@gmail.com;
alibensted@gmail.com; Berkman, Lisa; freece45@gmail.com
Additional Comments on Garden Street Conversion

Dear Yi-An Huang,
We write to add to the voices of our Walker Street neighbors. We concur with the letters already sent and must express
our deep concern over the traffic changes made without proper process or consideration of its impact on those of us
living adjacent to Garden Street.
We live precisely on Walker Street sharp curve to the left (at 60 Walker) and can testify to the difficulties this change has
caused. The added danger to our children and elderly from increased traffic on our small street is marked and
frightening. (It will be worse when snow narrows the street further in the winter months to come.) More cars than ever
are also illegally parked at the “dog leg” to the left on Walker Street and block the increased traffic now diverting to
Walker Street to avoid Garden. Trucks cannot make the Walker Street curve, and further endanger everyone by
stopping traffic and having to back up all the way to Garden since they can no longer get through. The noise of horns
honking and back up beeping signals has awoken us three mornings this week before 6am. It has added an extra level of
exhaustion to these traffic changes.
As a pedestrian who walks from Garden to the Square and campus daily, I can also testify that I have already had close
calls and have had to dodge cyclists when even attempting to cross Garden Street at any point now. The cyclists do not
stop at street corners and do not consider the welfare of pedestrians. More cyclists are also now on the sidewalks on
Garden Street and they ignore the regulations to stop for pedestrians in the cross walks. You are courting disaster with
this new traffic pattern and with the practice by cyclists of simply pressing on through intersections, ignoring pedestrians
in the process of crossing.
Please reconsider the changes you have made to Garden Street. You have reduced our quality of life in the
neighborhood and are actively endangering many who seek to walk safely in the neighborhood in which they live.
With deep concern,
Kay and Jack Shelemay

Kay Kaufman Shelemay
G. Gordon Watts Professor of Music and
Professor of African and African American Studies
Harvard University
Music Building, 3 Oxford Street
Cambridge, MA 02138
Cell: 617-792-4493

Attachment: Kay Kaufman Shelemay Additional Comments on Garden Street Conversion (COM 913 #2022 : A communication was received

Perez, Lori

living adjacent to Garden Street.
We live precisely on Walker Street sharp curve to the left (at 60 Walker) and can testify to the difficulties this change has
caused. The added danger to our children and elderly from increased traffic on our small street is marked and
frightening. (It will be worse when snow narrows the street further in the winter months to come.) More cars than ever
are also illegally parked at the “dog leg” to the left on Walker Street and block the increased traffic now diverting to
Walker Street to avoid Garden. Trucks cannot make the Walker Street curve, and further endanger everyone by
stopping traffic and having to back up all the way to Garden since they can no longer get through. The noise of horns
honking and back up beeping signals has awoken us three mornings this week before 6am. It has added an extra level of
exhaustion to these traffic changes.
As a pedestrian who walks from Garden to the Square and campus daily, I can also testify that I have already had close
calls and have had to dodge cyclists when even attempting to cross Garden Street at any point now. The cyclists do not
stop at street corners and do not consider the welfare of pedestrians. More cyclists are also now on the sidewalks on
Garden Street and they ignore the regulations to stop for pedestrians in the cross walks. You are courting disaster with
this new traffic pattern and with the practice by cyclists of simply pressing on through intersections, ignoring pedestrians
in the process of crossing.
Please reconsider the changes you have made to Garden Street. You have reduced our quality of life in the
neighborhood and are actively endangering many who seek to walk safely in the neighborhood in which they live.
With deep concern,

Packet Pg. 214

Andrews <cushman@fas.harvard.edu>, Taylor Lowe <tlowe@uchicago.edu>, sam.reece02138@gmail.com
<sam.reece02138@gmail.com>, Ellen Harkavy <eharkavy@gmail.com>, steven seeche
<stevenseeche1@hotmail.com>, Redor, Dylan <dredor@jd20.law.harvard.edu>, Walter Condit
<wlcondit@gmail.com>, Kathy Caple <kathycaple@gmail.com>, Shelemay, Kay K.
<shelemay@fas.harvard.edu>, Adam Baratz <adam.baratz@gmail.com>, Berkman, Lisa
<lberkman@hsph.harvard.edu>, Dan Anderson <dan@andersonporter.com>, Janelle Fisher
<jsmartfisher@gmail.com>, Singer, Judith D. <judith_singer@harvard.edu>, Eric Ward
<enw1776@yahoo.com>, Nan Soule <soulearama@hotmail.com>, Lisa Sebesta <lsebesta@gmail.com>,
Grimsted, Patricia K. <grimsted@fas.harvard.edu>, Debby Pugatch Kernochan <dkernochan@gmail.com>,
Elizabeth Dempster <eodempster@post.harvard.edu>, Erik Sebesta <erik.sebesta@gmail.com>, Erin Dullea
<erindullea@hotmail.com>, Jan Emlen <janemlen@gmail.com>
Subject: Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion
Dear Yi-An Huang:
We appreciate your letter even though it does not address our concerns.
The fact that you consulted with the City Solicitor [Nancy Glowa] on the legality of moving forward with the
Garden Street changes would indicate that you were aware of the legal requirement for the Traffic Board to
hear our petition before implementing traffic changes. The appropriate and legal steps to have taken were to
1) appoint three new members to the Board, 2) hear our petition, and then 3) determine how best to move
forward with the substantial changes to our neighborhood’s traffic patterns. There is little doubt that your
process has been backwards: 1) redirect traffic, 2) look at our petition, 3) recruit a new Board. Really?
Cambridge is perhaps the best run city in the Commonwealth, and you’ve approached this project backwards.
Further, our letter to you of October 30th referred specifically to the increased traffic volume of both cars and
trucks, as well as the unacceptable vehicle speeds on Walker Street. Our safety has been compromised.
Someone is going to get hurt: A child, a dog walker, a bicyclist or scooterist, a pedestrian, it is just a matter of
time, and soon daylight savings will make conditions worse. Perhaps additional signage would help, or a
couple of speed bumps along Walker between Garden and Shepard? You’re the expert, and we need your help
on these issues.
Yes, the residents of Walker Street feel “unheard and frustrated”. Perhaps your next letter can remedy these
feelings as well as the issues that caused them.
Thank you,
Frank & Sam Reece
45 Garden Street

Attachment: Kay and Jack Shelemay Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 914 #2022 : A communication was received from Kay and

Nan Soule; Natalie Bao Tram Le; Newbury, Lee; Nolan, Patricia; Pat Grimsted; Rick Sullo;
Riley, Kate; Sabina Islam; Sarah Ward; Simmons, Denise; Sue Miller; Taylor Lowe; Toner,

Karen Davis; jean woodward; sam.reece02138@gmail.com; steven seeche; to: Andrew
Liedtka
Re: Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion

All,
Informal traffic study day 1:
Date: Wednesday 11/2/2022
Time: 4:57pm - 5:27pm
Vehicles: 44
Hourly Rate: 88/hr
For analytical context, when the city conducted a traffic study on Tuesday June 14, 2022, there were 290 Westbound
vehicles on Garden Street per hour in the 4:30-5:30 time block. Walker street has taken a full 30% of the pre-change
traffic burden!
We have seen the street go from a place where kids were occasionally interrupted when throwing a football in the
street to 1.5 cars/minute - a rate at which if they're not careful crossing, there could be a tragedy!
I will keep logging data at different days and times to generate a convincing case to the city. And, hopefully no one will
get hurt.
Joe
On Wed, Nov 2, 2022 at 8:56 PM Peter Robinson <d.peter.robinson@gmail.com> wrote:
Adding to your info Joe and Frank, an empty school bus went down Walker St around 5 pm yesterday. I'm pretty
confident that is not something we've seen before. Not sure how it navigated the corner.
Pete Robinson
33 Walker St

Attachment: Joe Adiletta Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 915 #2022 : A communication was received from Joe Adiletta)

Perez, Lori

1

Packet Pg. 216

On Wed, Nov 2, 2022 at 5:31 PM Joe Adiletta <adiletta@gmail.com> wrote:
Frank & Sam,
In support of this view, I am conducting my own traffic survey documenting the increase in volume. As it happens, an
elderly woman with a walker was making her way around the corner about 30 mins ago and almost got hit by a
truck! See the attached photo. You are correct, it’s just a matter of time. The tradeoff of cyclist safety for pedestrian
and child safety is unimaginable, really. Oh, by the way the majority of this traffic increase now drives right past
Graham & Parks elementary school!
The street was a route that was walked by many (Elizabeth Warren included), where our children played. No
longer. We will continue to seek recourse with the city. This was not only completely predictable but also avoidable.
Joe

Attachment: Joe Adiletta Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 915 #2022 : A communication was received from Joe Adiletta)

3.69.a

2

Packet Pg. 217

Attachment: Joe Adiletta Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 915 #2022 : A communication was received from Joe Adiletta)

3.69.a

3

Packet Pg. 218

3.69.a

Dear Yi-An Huang:
We appreciate your letter even though it does not address our concerns.
The fact that you consulted with the City Solicitor [Nancy Glowa] on the legality of moving forward with the
Garden Street changes would indicate that you were aware of the legal requirement for the Traffic Board to
hear our petition before implementing traffic changes. The appropriate and legal steps to have taken were
to 1) appoint three new members to the Board, 2) hear our petition, and then 3) determine how best to
move forward with the substantial changes to our neighborhood’s traffic patterns. There is little doubt that
your process has been backwards: 1) redirect traffic, 2) look at our petition, 3) recruit a new Board. Really?
Cambridge is perhaps the best run city in the Commonwealth, and you’ve approached this project
backwards.
Further, our letter to you of October 30th referred specifically to the increased traffic volume of both cars
and trucks, as well as the unacceptable vehicle speeds on Walker Street. Our safety has been compromised.
Someone is going to get hurt: A child, a dog walker, a bicyclist or scooterist, a pedestrian, it is just a matter
of time, and soon daylight savings will make conditions worse. Perhaps additional signage would help, or a
couple of speed bumps along Walker between Garden and Shepard? You’re the expert, and we need your
help on these issues.
Yes, the residents of Walker Street feel “unheard and frustrated”. Perhaps your next letter can remedy
these feelings as well as the issues that caused them.
Thank you,
Frank & Sam Reece
45 Garden Street

Attachment: Joe Adiletta Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 915 #2022 : A communication was received from Joe Adiletta)

On Wed, Nov 2, 2022 at 5:23 PM Franklin Reece <freece45@gmail.com> wrote:

4

Packet Pg. 219

3.70.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Guillaume Bouchard <guillaume.bouchard04@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 3:52 PM
City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke; Huang, Yi-An
Clerk; info@cambridgebikesafety.org
Brattle St Bike Lanes

Hi all,
I write with concern for the health and wellbeing of fellow residents. I want to convey the following points for
your consideration:

•
•
•
•

Thank City staff for implementing the Garden St. lanes, and for the upcoming protected bike lanes on River St.
and Hampshire St..
Point out the risks of a multiple-month delay to people riding bikes on this stretch; share your personal
experience if relevant.
Ask that the city proceed with the project immediately, using temporary barriers until the concrete barriers
can be installed.
Note that use of temporary traffic control devices is acceptable within the historic district with no further
approval needed.

In addition to endangering residents who are trying to move safely and securely through our streets, delaying this work
continues to discourage more of our residents to take the necessary and highly beneficial step of choosing active
transportation over private vehicles.
Kindest regards,
Guillaume Bouchard
Riverside resident

Attachment: Guillaume Bouchard Brattle St Bike Lanes (COM 916 #2022 : A communication was received from Guillaume Bouchard)

Perez, Lori

Anna Bensted; Sarah Ward; Mary O'Meara; Miya Cain; Lino Pertile; Loray McDuffie;
Marion Boulicault; John Petrowsky; Kay Shelemay; Jessica Cheng; Joe Umphres; Emily
Rogal; George Soule; William Sawyer; Newbury, Lee; Joan Wickersham; Liz Robinson;
Maggie Baratz; Pete Robinson; Elana Messer; Zoe Anderson; Katya Slive; Barry Wohl;
Doug Elmendorf; Sabina Islam; Jo Chaffee; Dara Cohen; Kate Clark; Aron Wander;
George Emlen; Joe Adiletta; Arthur Dempster; Ali Sullo; Natalie Bao Tram Le; Anne
Pierce; Douglas Bauer; Karen Dynan; jean woodward; MB Flanders; Isaac Cheng; Beth
Gamse; Larry Lesser; Kaela; Firey Cushman; Taylor Lowe; sam.reece02138@gmail.com;
Ellen Harkavy; steven seeche; Dylan Redor; Walter Condit; Kathy Caple; Jack Shelemay;
Adam Baratz; Lisa Berkman; Dan Anderson; Janelle Fisher; Judy Singer; Eric Ward; Nan
Soule; Lisa Sebesta; Pat Grimsted; Debby Pugatch Kernochan; Elizabeth Dempster; Erik
Sebesta; Erin Dullea; Jan Emlen
Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion

Dear Yi-An Huang:
We appreciate your letter even though it does not address our concerns.
The fact that you consulted with the City Solicitor [Nancy Glowa] on the legality of moving forward with the
Garden Street changes would indicate that you were aware of the legal requirement for the Traffic Board to
hear our petition before implementing traffic changes. The appropriate and legal steps to have taken were to
1) appoint three new members to the Board, 2) hear our petition, and then 3) determine how best to move
forward with the substantial changes to our neighborhood’s traffic patterns. There is little doubt that your
process has been backwards: 1) redirect traffic, 2) look at our petition, 3) recruit a new Board. Really?
Cambridge is perhaps the best run city in the Commonwealth, and you’ve approached this project backwards.
Further, our letter to you of October 30th referred specifically to the increased traffic volume of both cars and
trucks, as well as the unacceptable vehicle speeds on Walker Street. Our safety has been compromised.
Someone is going to get hurt: A child, a dog walker, a bicyclist or scooterist, a pedestrian, it is just a matter of
time, and soon daylight savings will make conditions worse. Perhaps additional signage would help, or a
couple of speed bumps along Walker between Garden and Shepard? You’re the expert, and we need your help
on these issues.
Yes, the residents of Walker Street feel “unheard and frustrated”. Perhaps your next letter can remedy these
feelings as well as the issues that caused them.
Thank you,

Attachment: Frank & Sam Reece Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 917 #2022 : A communication was received from Frank & Sam

3.71.b

Frank & Sam Reece

Cushman; George Emlen; George Soule; Isaac Cheng; Jack Shelemay; Jan Emlen; Jane
Mansbridge; Janelle Fisher; Jay Wickersham; Jessica Cheng; Jo Chaffee; Joan
Wickersham; Joe Umphres; John Petrowsky; Judy Singer; Julia Schlozman; Julie Kobick;
Kaela; Karen Dynan; Kate Clark; Kathy Caple; Katya Slive; Kay Shelemay; Ken Osgood;
Larry Lesser; Lewis Bushnell; Lino Pertile; Lisa Berkman; Lisa Sebesta; Liz Robinson; Loray
McDuffie; MB Flanders; Maggie Baratz; Mallon, Alanna; Marion Boulicault; Mary
O'Meara; McGovern, Marc; McKenna, Brooke; Michael Lauber; Miya Cain; Nadia Davila;
Nan Soule; Natalie Bao Tram Le; Newbury, Lee; Nolan, Patricia; Pat Grimsted; Pete
Robinson; Rick Sullo; Riley, Kate; Sabina Islam; Sarah Ward; Simmons, Denise; Sue Miller;
Taylor Lowe; Toner, Paul; Walter Condit; Watkins, Kathy; William Sawyer; Wolfe, Andreas;
Zoe Anderson; cc: Karen Davis; jean woodward; sam.reece02138@gmail.com; steven
seeche; to: Andrew Liedtka
Re: Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion
image_67508481.JPG

Frank & Sam,
In support of this view, I am conducting my own traffic survey documenting the increase in volume. As it happens, an
elderly woman with a walker was making her way around the corner about 30 mins ago and almost got hit by a
truck! See the attached photo. You are correct, it’s just a matter of time. The tradeoff of cyclist safety for pedestrian
and child safety is unimaginable, really. Oh, by the way the majority of this traffic increase now drives right past Graham
& Parks elementary school!
The street was a route that was walked by many (Elizabeth Warren included), where our children played. No
longer. We will continue to seek recourse with the city. This was not only completely predictable but also avoidable.
Joe

Attachment: 2Frank & Sam Reece Follow-Up on Garden Street Conversion (COM 917 #2022 : A communication was received from Frank & Sam

Dear Yi-An Huang:
We appreciate your letter even though it does not address our concerns.
The fact that you consulted with the City Solicitor [Nancy Glowa] on the legality of moving forward with the
Garden Street changes would indicate that you were aware of the legal requirement for the Traffic Board to
hear our petition before implementing traffic changes. The appropriate and legal steps to have taken were to
1) appoint three new members to the Board, 2) hear our petition, and then 3) determine how best to move
forward with the substantial changes to our neighborhood’s traffic patterns. There is little doubt that your
process has been backwards: 1) redirect traffic, 2) look at our petition, 3) recruit a new Board. Really?
Cambridge is perhaps the best run city in the Commonwealth, and you’ve approached this project backwards.
Further, our letter to you of October 30th referred specifically to the increased traffic volume of both cars
and trucks, as well as the unacceptable vehicle speeds on Walker Street. Our safety has been compromised.
Someone is going to get hurt: A child, a dog walker, a bicyclist or scooterist, a pedestrian, it is just a matter of
time, and soon daylight savings will make conditions worse. Perhaps additional signage would help, or a

help on these issues.

feelings as well as the issues that caused them.

3.71.d

3

Packet Pg. 232

3.72.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Ellen Blumenthal <eb@blumenthalmd.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 5:45 PM
City Council
City Clerk; Lynn Cetrulo; Cetrulo, Lawrence
Re: Cambridge Traffic/Bike Lanes/Garden St Re-Alignment

Dear City Council:
I am a resident of Linnaean St and agree with Larry Cetrulo about the congestion on all of the residential streets now
that Garden St has been made one way. Here are my concerns:
1—While walking today on Holly Street I agree that it is no longer safe to even step off the sidewalk. It used to be a
street for walkers, residents and a few bikes. Now only cars
2—While crossing garden street on my walk, I have been nearly hit by bicyclists. I have not felt unsafe from cars because
they stop at crosswalks for the most part. On the other hand bicycles rarely stop for pedestrians and it is all the more
dangerous because they ride right next to the curb. Cars do not!
3--I do not mean to privilege cars, but drivers tend to be more careful than scooters or bicyclists.
I choose to privilege people who walk to get around Cambridge, and you have not in any way taken us into account in
your decision making.
Please think of the large part of the population you serve and rescind this poorly taken decision.
Respectfully,
Ellen Blumenthal
33 Linnaean St, Cambridge

——
Ellen Blumenthal, MD
eb@blumenthalmd.com
617-312-6792
The information transmitted in this electronic communication is intended only for the person or entity to whom it is addressed and
may contain confidential and/or privileged material. Any review, retransmission, dissemination or other use of or taking any
action based upon this information by persons or entities other than the intended recipient is prohibited. If you received this information
in error, please contact me by email or at 617-312-6792

On Oct 31, 2022, at 5:12 PM, Cetrulo, Lawrence <LCetrulo@cetllp.com> wrote:
City Council:
1. Your terrible decision to reconfigure Garden St. has already had the entirely foreseeable
consequence of transforming Holly Ave (all 100 yards and one travel lane of it) into a high speed short
cut from Madison St to Huron Ave.
2. Your shortsightedness has, overnight, taken Holly Ave. from a quiet residential street where families
with young children reside to a dangerously overcrowded cut through.
3. Did any one consider what were the likely consequences of rerouting traffic in a residential
neighborhood to accommodate high speed and ‘traffic-rules-ignoring‘ bicyclists?
4. Come to Holly Ave. and watch the traffic that now speeds through what used to be a safe place for
kids to walk.
Respectfully Submitted,
Larry Cetrulo

Attachment: Ellen Blumenthal Cambridge TrafficBike LanesGarden St Re-Alignment (COM 918 #2022 : A communication was received from

Perez, Lori

Packet Pg. 233

3.72.a

Lawrence G. Cetrulo
Cetrulo LLP
Two Seaport Lane
Boston, Ma

On Oct 28, 2022, at 10:20 PM, Cetrulo, Lawrence <lcetrulo@cetllp.com> wrote:
City Council:
1. Your bike lane policies have destroyed the neighborhoods and rendered unsafe
Harvard Square, Inman Square, and now Garden Street, with no end to your ill-advised
assault on common sense in sight.
2. You have been cowed by a small minority of residents in a headlong rush to appease
a loud lobby at the expense of the safety, and neighborhood integrity.
3. The unsightly, disorganized, congested, dysfunctional and hazardous conditions of
our roads, sidewalks, parking spaces and access to neighborhood businesses would be
laughable were it not so patently offensive to the rights of a majority of Cambridge
residents.
4. I stand with those citizens who have been unheard and foreclosed from voicing
unequivocal objection to the City’s bike lane policies.
Respectfully Submitted,
Larry Cetrulo
46 Grozier Road
Cambridge
Lawrence G. Cetrulo, Esq.
Cetrulo LLP
Two Seaport Lane
Boston, Ma

Think Green! Please consider the impact on the environment before printing this e-mail.

individual or entity to whom they are addressed. If you have received this email in error please notify
the sender and destroy the original message.
IMPORTANT NOTICE - This email, including any attachment(s), may contain personal information of one
or more Massachusetts residents protected from unauthorized disclosure by the provisions of Chapter
93 H of the General Laws of Massachusetts. The recipient of this email is required to exercise reasonable
precautions to ensure the security of that information.
Cetrulo LLP Boston MA
**********************************************************************

Brattle St. protected bike lanes

Dear all,
Thank you for implementing the Garden St. lanes and the upcoming protected bike lanes on River St. and
Hampshire St.
I'm concerned about the delay in the Brattle St. protected bike lane project due to supply issues. I suggest that the
city proceeds with temporary barriers like cones, etc. This makes a significant difference when commuting by bike,
especially as it gets darker and colder this time of year. For example, the temporary cones marking the bike lane on
the Mass Ave bridge ahead of permanent installation make me feel much safer when biking across. This has
dramatically slowed vehicle speeds, so they usually go the speed limit.
Sincerely,
Elizabeth Petit

Wednesday, November 2, 2022 12:37 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
Clerk; info@cambridgebikesafety.org
proposed delay in bike lane implementation

City Council,
It has come to my attention that the City proposes to delay initial generation of bike lanes on Brattle Street until
Spring 2023, and this delay, at least in part, was caused by a failure to put out for bid supplies for 7 weeks after the
Aug 8 public meeting. This is disappointing and unacceptable. In the future, the City must demonstrate better
planning. Temporary cones, barrels, or other barriers should be erected on the relevant portions of Brattle St. and
done right away. Doing so, especially before Winter when slippery conditions make commuting less safe for drivers
and cyclists, will almost certainly prevent more traffic injuries and deaths.
Thanks for your consideration,
Ben Fox
Cambridgeport

btantony <btantony@aol.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 4:41 PM
City Manager; City Council
City Clerk; info@cambridgeforall.org
Garden St

Dear City Councilors and City Manager,
I am extremely disappointed in your decision to allow Garden St to be converted to one-way despite the CSA petition
appealing the Traffic Director’s decision. According to the law, all work should be suspended until the Traffic Board hears
the appeal and reaches a decision. The statement from the City Manager that the TAB would take up the petitions after
the work of conversion has been done defies common sense and flouts the clear intent of that regulation.
It is unclear how the city could reach the decision to proceed in clear violation of its own laws. That said, your actions
are consistent with previous actions that ignore the needs and will of ordinary Cambridge citizens and small businesses.
I experienced first hand the results of your actions when I became embroiled in a traffic jam from Concord to Huron and
beyond because of the closure of Garden westbound. This jam lasted for two hours at least as I encountered it on my
return eastbound and saw the continuous crawling of traffic westbound in the dark. You might want to know that your
largesse to cyclists with respect to Garden St was not appreciated by all as I saw several cyclists weaving in and out of
stalled traffic westbound on Huron. (Guess they didn’t get the memo. )
One other issue that I would like to address is that I have heard from some of you that residents wanted the one way
Garden configuration. Such statements are truly disingenuous . There was NO real choice. It was one way and no
parking or two ways and no parking. That’s not a choice. That is autocratic decision making.
I am very disaffected by your actions and disappointed by a number of you personally. There are some of you who I
regard as friends. I have supported you and voted for you in the past. That will no longer be the case going forward.
You ignored petitions from almost 200 voters to inflict your ideological purity on ordinary folks who are not in the tank
with your cyclists’ lobby. And that is just untenable. Cambridge is not your fiefdom.
I do plan to actively work against you come next election. We may not succeed right away but I think that
notwithstanding our voting system, you can be voted out. Between your bike lane mania and the BEUDO 2035 - so you
can be first in the nation - ordinance - you would destroy Cambridge for the great middle class which every city needs to
survive.
And I am so disappointed in the new manager. Not off to good start. I would think someone with a sophisticated
background in healthcare policy would be smart enough to see through a rigged decision making apparatus .
Sincerely,
Barbara Anthony
1580 Mass Ave
02138

3.77.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Subject:

Aaron Shakow <ashakow@post.harvard.edu>
Monday, October 31, 2022 3:41 PM
City Council; Clerk
Please support the Cambridge Lab Regulation Zoning Amendment

Dear Mayor and Councilors,
I write as a longtime (27-year) Cambridge resident and member of the medical-scientific community, in strong support
of the Lab Regulation Zoning Amendment.
Cambridge is blessed to have so many institutions where science is explored and used for the public benefit. In addition
to their direct contribution, commercial laboratories are a source of revenue for the city, and help fund critical
amenities.
But allowing unchecked expansion of laboratory space in order to support the municipal tax base risks destroying our
community in order to save it. In an unregulated real estate market, highly-profitable biotech labs crowd out other civic
economies; neighborhoods dominated by them are transformed from living communities to generic office parks as
residents and small businesses flee to more affordable locations.
The proposed ordinance is carefully crafted to exempt laboratories used mainly for health and educational services, and
to limit disruption of this city's important laboratory sector while preserving our local spaces.
After the financial crisis of 2008, the old joke that Harvard is a hedge fund moonlighting as a university got a lot of play.
We must not let Cambridge become a laboratory services company moonlighting as a city. The social fabric of our
community has to be protected, or we will lose it. Please support the Cambridge Lab Regulation Zoning Amendment.
Thank you very much for your time and consideration.
Respectfully,
Aaron Shakow
4 Newton St. #3

Attachment: Aaron Shakow Please support the Cambridge Lab Regulation Zoning Amendment (COM 923 #2022 : A communication was

Perez, Lori

3.78.a

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Aaron Greiner <aaronbgreiner@gmail.com>
Monday, October 31, 2022 4:19 PM
Huang, Yi-An; City Council; O'Riordan, Owen; McKenna, Brooke
info@cambridgebikesafety.org; Clerk
Brattle Street Bike Lanes

Hello,
Thank you for your work installing protected bike lanes on Garden Street and the upcoming protected lane projects on
River and Hampshire Streets. I am writing today because I heard that due to supplies constraints the implementation of
the Brattle St. protected lane project may be delayed to the spring. This is a dangerous decision and one that can be
easily rectified.
I use my bike for transpiration year-round. I find winter to be the most dangerous time to bike. When it snows, snow
piles up next to the curb, pushing out parked vehicles and narrowing the roadway. This leaves little to no space for a
driver to pass me when I am riding my bike on a busy street such as Brattle and leads to close passes that have a high
potential for crashes. With protected bike lanes, however, I have a clear and safe path (when plowed, which generally
Cambridge is quite good at!).
I understand that supplies constraints mean you are unable to install the project as designed this fall. However, if you
are able to stripe the road and separate the bike facilities with cones, it will be a large improvement and provide a safe
facility through the winter. The bike lanes on the Mass Ave bridge have been protected using cones for a year and have
worked great.
I look forward to seeing this project implemented with cones this fall, and then fully to the design next spring.
Best,
Aaron

Attachment: Aaron Greiner Brattle Street Bike Lanes (COM 924 #2022 : A communication was received from Aaron Greiner)

Perez, Lori

Dynan; jean woodward; MB Flanders; Isaac Cheng; Beth Gamse; Larry Lesser; Kaela; Firey
Cushman; Taylor Lowe; sam.reece02138@gmail.com; Ellen Harkavy; steven seeche;
Dylan Redor; Walter Condit; Kathy Caple; Jack Shelemay; Adam Baratz; Lisa Berkman;
Dan Anderson; Janelle Fisher; Judy Singer; Eric Ward; Nan Soule; Lisa Sebesta; Pat
Grimsted; Debby Pugatch Kernochan; Elizabeth Dempster; Erik Sebesta; Erin Dullea; Jan
Emlen
Unsafe pedestrian conditions on Walker Street due to City's changes to Garden Street

Dear City Manager and City Council members,
As a 20-year resident of Walker Street, I am writing to state agreement with the numerous concerns you have heard
from other Walker Street residents, regarding the unsafe pedestrian conditions caused by the City’s recent changes to
Garden Street.
The evidence shows how the City’s traffic changes have caused a significant increase in cut-through traffic on Walker
Street:
• A dramatic and observed increase in traffic volumes to approximately 1.5 vehicles / minute.
• Much faster and unsafe speeds of travel by cut-through vehicles.
• Travel by school buses and trucks that cannot safely make the 90 degree turn in the street.
• Unsafe conditions at the turn from Garden Street into Walker Street.
Before the City made these changes, Walker Street was a safe pedestrian environment, where walkers and bicyclists
coexisted with a limited number of local-access cars and trucks, moving at safe speeds.
It is unfortunate that the City’s well-intentioned but flawed attempt to improve bicycle travel on Garden Street have
caused these negative impacts to walking – an equally important and environmentally sustainable way to get around the
city. Not everyone can ride a bicycle – but everyone can walk, including children, the elderly, and the disabled. By
creating an unsafe pedestrian environment on Walker Street, the City has violated its own policies of providing safe,
healthy, sustainable, and equitable movement for all citizens throughout the city
To remedy these problems, the City must quickly develop and implement, through a process of public review and
comment, a detailed and effective set of changes that will ensure pedestrian safety on and around Walker Street, and
restore the street to the safe and sustainable environment that it once was.

Attachment: Jay Wickersham Unsafe pedestrian conditions on Walker Street due to City's changes to Garden Street (COM 925 #2022 : A

Perez, Lori

Jay Wickersham

4.1

City of Cambridge

R-1
FIRST IN COUNCIL
November 7, 2022

COUNCILLOR SIMMONS
MAYOR SIDDIQUI
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN
COUNCILLOR AZEEM
COUNCILLOR CARLONE
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN
VICE MAYOR MALLON
COUNCILLOR NOLAN
COUNCILLOR TONER
WHEREAS:

It has come to the City Council’s attention that the Harvard Union of Clerical and
Technical Workers, whose contract with Harvard University expired on September 30,
has been engaged in contract negotiations with the university since that time, and
concerns have been raised that the salary ranges being offered by Harvard do not meet
the current cost of living demands; and

WHEREAS:

Representatives for the HUCTW, which represents approximately 5,000 Harvard
employees, have reported that these negotiations have been productive on a number of
fronts, but the two sides have yet to reach an agreement around appropriate wage
increases, with the union correctly noting that their members are feeling financially
squeezed in a time of rising rents, rising costs of food and fuel, increased inflation, and
the threat of a recession looming; and

WHEREAS:

Representatives of the HUCTW have noted that Harvard University has not given any
clear rationale as to why an institution with an endowment worth $53,200,000,000 is
unwilling or unable to provide the adequate cost-of-living adjustments to the salary
ranges being asked for by the union; and

WHEREAS:

The clerical and technical workers give their all to Harvard University on a daily basis,
they are part of the institution’s very backbone, and during these especially challenging
times, it is incumbent upon Harvard University to meet the moment and find a way to
bring some badly needed financial piece of mind to the HUCTW union members going
forward; now therefore be it

RESOLVED:

That the City Council formally go on record in urging Harvard University to meet the
salary demands being made by the Harvard Union of Clerical and Technical Workers
in their ongoing contract negotiations; and be it further

RESOLVED:

That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward suitably engrossed copies of
this resolution to Harvard University President Lawrence Bacow, to Harvard’s Director
of Government & Community Relations Tom Lucey, and to HUCTW President Carrie
E. Barbash, on behalf of the entire City Council.

Packet Pg. 244

4.1

In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by the affirmative vote of nine members.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

WHEREAS:

The City Council was deeply saddened at learning of the death of Mary E. Hunter on
October 13, 2022 at the age of 91; and

WHEREAS:

Mary was the beloved wife of 66 years to Robert J. Hunter, retired MDC Police
Officer, loving mother of Nancy Coleman and her husband Robert, Patricia DePrimio
and her husband Joseph, Mary Kissane, Susan Cyr, Linda Foley and the late Robert J.
Hunter Jr., sister of Jean Ryan, Paul McDougall and the late John McDougall; and

WHEREAS:

Mary’s passing will leave a void in the lives of all her surviving family and she will be
greatly missed by all her grandchildren, great grandchildren, nieces, nephews, relatives
and dear friends; and

WHEREAS:

A lifelong Cambridge resident, Mary and her husband Robert enjoyed their nightly
strolls along North Mass Ave. stopping at familiar places along the way; and

WHEREAS:

Mary proudly worked as a Crossing Guard for the City of Cambridge for more than 30
years, greeting all she met at the corner of Cedar and Rindge Ave. with a smile, rain or
shine; now therefore be it

RESOLVED:

That the City Council go on record extending its deepest sympathy for the family of
Mary Hunter at this time of such personal loss; and be it further

RESOLVED:

That the City Clerk be and hereby is requested to forward a suitably engrossed copy of
this resolution to the Hunter family on behalf of the entire City Council.

VICE MAYOR MALLON
COUNCILLOR NOLAN
COUNCILLOR AZEEM
WHEREAS:

There are more than 22 million living veterans who served our Nation in times of
peace and war—many of them willingly entered harm’s way to fight for our freedoms;
and

WHEREAS:

These veterans have diverse religious beliefs and come from varying backgrounds and
ethnicities, but share a desire to protect the country by serving around the world and
here at home; and

WHEREAS:

On Veterans Day, we reflect on the sacrifices of those who have put on the uniform to
serve in the United States military; let us honor our veterans who proved their heroism
and love of country, time and time again; and

WHEREAS:

We shall always be grateful for the noble sacrifices made by these veterans; we can
never adequately repay them; but we can honor and respect them for their service and
their sacrifice, and we can pledge that we will ask for this sacrifice only through
careful, honest, and conscious decisions rooted in our founding principles of justice
and human rights; and

WHEREAS:

As we consider the sacrifices and efforts of our veterans, we will never forget the
individuals of past wars for whom there is still no accounting; now therefore be it

RESOLVED:

That the City Council go on record urging all residents to honor the people who have
defended our country, as well as those who are serving today, by commemorating
Veterans Day on Friday, November 11, 2022.

Packet Pg. 252

5.1

City of Cambridge

O-1
FIRST IN COUNCIL
November 7, 2022

COUNCILLOR TONER
COUNCILLOR SIMMONS
COUNCILLOR CARLONE
WHEREAS:

The recent change of part of Garden Street from a two way to a one-way street has
caused concerns about overflow traffic on neighboring side streets; and

WHEREAS:

Four Community meetings and an in-person community open house were held ahead
of implementation, and a fifth was held on November 9th, 2022, with more community
meetings to follow; yet many residents were not aware of the proposed changes until
implementation; and

WHEREAS:

The Traffic and Transportation Department is continuing to monitor the situation,
including via traffic counting and other methods: and

WHEREAS:

The Traffic and Transportation Department is continuing to monitor the situation,
including via traffic counting and other methods and will conduct at least two more
listening sessions on Tuesday, November 29 at 6:30 pm and Tuesday, December 13 at
6 pm and will need some time to analyze and process the data and feedback it received;
and

WHEREAS:

Many residents at the November 9th meeting and through emails to the City Council
have offered many thoughtful ideas for ameliorating the negative impact making
Garden Street a one way has had on neighboring side streets, including, but not limited
to, restoring the section of Garden Street from Bond to Huron as two way for
automobile traffic and improving traffic calming and signage on Walker Street to
improve safety and reduce traffic flow; and

WHEREAS:

Efforts to address these concerns will not involve removal of separated bike lanes on
Garden Street; now therefore be it,

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to direct the Traffic, Parking, and
Transportation Department and Department of Public Works to meet with and receive
input from residents living on the streets in the impacted area to discuss strategies to
mitigate and reduce overflow and cut through traffic, including the aforementioned
proposals, or other traffic calming or traffic diversion methods, and report back to the
Council on any short term recommendations no later than December 19th, 2022

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to provide a final report on how the
concerns are being addressed, no later than March 27, 2023

Packet Pg. 253

5.1

In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by a yea and nay vote:Yeas 9; Nays 0; Absent 0.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Packet Pg. 254

5.2

City of Cambridge

O-2
FIRST IN COUNCIL
November 7, 2022

VICE MAYOR MALLON
COUNCILLOR AZEEM
COUNCILLOR CARLONE
COUNCILLOR ZONDERVAN
COUNCILLOR MCGOVERN
COUNCILLOR NOLAN
WHEREAS:

The City of Cambridge Vision Zero Action plan adopted in March of 2016, and
updated in February of 2018 states; “Vision Zero is a strategy to eliminate all traffic
fatalities and severe injuries, while increasing safe, healthy, equitable mobility for all.
The Vision Zero approach consists first and foremost of an acknowledgment that
crashes are preventable. By examining the factors that cause crashes, from
infrastructure to behavior and societal factors, we can make the changes necessary to
eliminate traffic fatalities and serious injuries. Vision Zero also acknowledges that
human beings will always make mistakes, so we must have systems in place to ensure
that they are not fatal or life changing;’ and

WHEREAS:

Our City’s streets are currently being redesigned to better protect more vulnerable road
users, which has increased the number of bicycles and pedestrians on our streets and
sidewalks every day; and

WHEREAS:

We must continue to implement new safety improvements to our Traffic Regulations
to meet our adopted Vision Zero Action Plan goals of eliminating all traffic fatalities
and severe injuries; and

WHEREAS:

In order to meet their Vision Zero goals, Washington D.C recently voted to ban right
turn on red movements district-wide, joining New York City as the second City in the
United States to do so, with Ann Arbor, Michigan joining the cause in October to ban
right turn on red movements in their downtown area; and

WHEREAS:

In 2008, the Washington District’s Department of Transportation selected 100 pilot
locations to study the “No Turn on Red” implementation as a protection for vulnerable
road users, and the study of that pilot found that: “vehicle-to-vehicle conflicts dropped
by 97% after the “no turn on red” signs were installed. The number of times drivers
failed to yield to pedestrians when the light was red dropped by 92%. Drivers even did
a better job yielding to pedestrians when their light was green, with violations dropping
by 59%;” and

Packet Pg. 255

5.2

WHEREAS:

This movement is already banned in over half the City of Cambridge’s intersections
and the Cambridge Traffic Regulations regarding “No Turn on Red” language
currently states:
“Section 4.5 Traffic Control Legend:
(c) Steady Red Signal
(2) No driver of a vehicle facing a red indication shall make a right turn where
official “No Turn on Red” traffic signs are installed and maintained prohibiting such
turn, at intersections as described in Schedule 4A incorporated herein and made a part
hereof available at the Traffic Department;” and

WHEREAS:

Banning turns on red Citywide is a safety improvement the City of Cambridge should
consider in order to continue to protect vulnerable road users like pedestrians and
cyclists; now therefore be it

ORDERED:

That the City Manager is directed to work with the Law Department and the Traffic,
Parking and Transportation Department to investigate how to ban turns on red
Citywide, with the flexibility to permit turns on red where Traffic, Parking, and
Transportation Department deems it allowable without any negative safety impacts;
and be it further

ORDERED:

That the City Manager is directed to contact the Massachusetts Department of
Conservation and Recreation, and the Massachusetts Department of Transportation, to
begin discussions of banning turns on red movements on roadways in Cambridge
controlled by those state entities, with the intent they would have the flexibility to

permit turns on red where the Mass. DOT deems it allowable without any
negative safety impacts; and be it further
ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to report back to the City Council on
this matter in a timely manner.
In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by the affirmative vote of nine members.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Packet Pg. 256

5.2.a

City of Cambridge

O-2
FIRST IN COUNCIL
November 7, 2022

WHEREAS:

The City of Cambridge Vision Zero Action plan adopted in March of 2016, and
updated in February of 2018 states; “Vision Zero is a strategy to eliminate all traffic
fatalities and severe injuries, while increasing safe, healthy, equitable mobility for all.
The Vision Zero approach consists first and foremost of an acknowledgment that
crashes are preventable. By examining the factors that cause crashes, from
infrastructure to behavior and societal factors, we can make the changes necessary to
eliminate traffic fatalities and serious injuries. Vision Zero also acknowledges that
human beings will always make mistakes, so we must have systems in place to ensure
that they are not fatal or life changing;’ and

WHEREAS:

Our City’s streets are currently being redesigned to better protect more vulnerable road
users, which has increased the number of bicycles and pedestrians on our streets and
sidewalks every day; and

WHEREAS:

We must continue to implement new safety improvements to our Traffic Regulations
to meet our adopted Vision Zero Action Plan goals of eliminating all traffic fatalities
and severe injuries; and

WHEREAS:

In order to meet their Vision Zero goals, Washington D.C recently voted to ban right
turn on red movements district-wide, joining New York City as the second City in the
United States to do so, with Ann Arbor, Michigan joining the cause in October to ban
right turn on red movements in their downtown area; and

WHEREAS:

In 2008, the Washington District’s Department of Transportation selected 100 pilot
locations to study the “No Turn on Red” implementation as a protection for vulnerable
road users, and the study of that pilot found that: “vehicle-to-vehicle conflicts dropped
by 97% after the “no turn on red” signs were installed. The number of times drivers
failed to yield to pedestrians when the light was red dropped by 92%. Drivers even did
a better job yielding to pedestrians when their light was green, with violations dropping
by 59%;” and

Attachment: #2 Original Order #2022_283 (POR 2022 #283 : Ban Turns on Red Citywide)

VICE MAYOR MALLON
COUNCILLOR AZEEM

Packet Pg. 257

5.2.a

WHEREAS:

This movement is already banned in over half the City of Cambridge’s intersections
and the Cambridge Traffic Regulations regarding “No Turn on Red” language
currently states:
“Section 4.5 Traffic Control Legend:

(2) No driver of a vehicle facing a red indication shall make a right turn where
official “No Turn on Red” traffic signs are installed and maintained prohibiting such
turn, at intersections as described in Schedule 4A incorporated herein and made a part
hereof available at the Traffic Department;” and
WHEREAS:

Banning turns on red Citywide is a safety improvement the City of Cambridge should
consider in order to continue to protect vulnerable road users like pedestrians and
cyclists; now therefore be it

ORDERED:

That the City Manager is directed to work with the Law Department and the Traffic,
Parking and Transportation Department to investigate how to ban turns on red
Citywide; and be it further

ORDERED:

That the City Manager is directed to contact the Massachusetts Department of
Conservation and Recreation, and the Massachusetts Department of Transportation, to
begin discussions of banning turns on red movements on roadways in Cambridge
controlled by those state entities; and be it further

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to report back to the City Council on
this matter in a timely manner.
In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by the affirmative vote of nine members.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Attachment: #2 Original Order #2022_283 (POR 2022 #283 : Ban Turns on Red Citywide)

(c) Steady Red Signal

Packet Pg. 258

5.3

City of Cambridge

O-3
FIRST IN COUNCIL
November 7, 2022

COUNCILLOR TONER
COUNCILLOR SIMMONS
COUNCILLOR NOLAN
WHEREAS:

In 2022, more than 62,000 people will be diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in the
United States and nearly 50,000 will die from the disease; and

WHEREAS:

Pancreatic cancer is the third leading cause of cancer death in the United States, and it
is projected to be become the second leading before 2030; and

WHEREAS:

Pancreatic cancer is the only major cancer with a five-year relative survival rate at just
11 percent; and

WHEREAS:

When symptoms of pancreatic cancer present themselves, it is generally late stage,
with the average patient living for about one-year after diagnosis while only 10 percent
of patients with an early diagnosis become disease-free after treatment; and

WHEREAS:

Pancreatic cancer is the fourth most common cause of cancer-related death in women
and men across the world; and

WHEREAS:

Disparities by race and socioeconomic status exist in the diagnosis and treatment of
pancreatic cancer, improved understanding of underlying causes could inform
interventions; and

WHEREAS:

It is estimated that in 2025, 557,688 new cases will be diagnosed globally; and

WHEREAS:

The good health and well-being of the residents of the Commonwealth are enhanced as
a direct result of increased awareness about pancreatic cancer and research into early
detection, causes, and effective treatments; now therefore be it

ORDERED:

That the City Council go on record recognizing November 17, 2022 as Pancreatic
Cancer Awareness Day in the City of Cambridge and urge all citizens of Cambridge to
take cognizance of this event and participate fittingly in its observance; and be it
further

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to direct the appropriate City staff to
light City Hall up in purple on November 17, 2022 to honor the people lost to the
disease and the on-going efforts to defeat this terrible form of cancer.

Packet Pg. 259

5.3

In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by the affirmative vote of nine members.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

Packet Pg. 260

5.4

City of Cambridge

O-4
FIRST IN COUNCIL
November 7, 2022

MAYOR SIDDIQUI
VICE MAYOR MALLON
WHEREAS:

The City of Cambridge has aggressive Parking, Transportation and Demand
Management goals for developers and employers in the City; and

WHEREAS:

In Envision Cambridge’s Mobility Plan, a recommended strategy and action is to:
“Encourage and incentivize the use of sustainable transportation by City employees
through increased transportation benefits and programming.”; and

WHEREAS:

The City of Cambridge current MBTA benefit is as follows:
• Non-union employees regularly scheduled to work 16 or more hours per week
in permanent positions or in temporary positions with an expected duration of
6 consecutive months or more are eligible for the MBTA Pass Reimbursement
Benefit of 65% of the cost of a monthly pass, up to $265/month.
• Union employees may be eligible for a similar benefit pursuant to their
collective bargaining agreements.

WHEREAS:

It has been recently reported that the City of Boston, as well as Cambridge-based
employers Google and Sanofi are entering into a 2 year pilot to allow their employees
to ride public transportation for free; and

WHEREAS:

This 2 year pilot is based on a program created by MIT in 2016 “that allows the
university to pay after-the-fact for individual trips taken by employees and students;”
and

WHEREAS:

The City of Cambridge has recently moved to implement a remote work schedule, and
the need for a monthly subsidized pass may have shifted to a less regular model for
many employees; and

WHEREAS:

To respond to this new workplace reality, the City should explore an alternative to the
current subsidized monthly MBTA pass to allow for greater flexibility with the express
goal of making it easier, and less expensive to take mass transit to work; now therefore
be it

ORDERED:

That the City Manager work with the Finance Department, Personnel, Payroll, and any
other related City departments to determine the feasibility of joining this pilot for two
(2) years; and be it further

ORDERED:

That the City Manager be and hereby is requested to report back to the City Council on
this matter in a timely manner.

Packet Pg. 261

5.4

In City Council November 7, 2022.
Adopted by the affirmative vote of nine members.
Attest:- Diane P. LeBlanc, City Clerk
A true copy;

ATTEST:Diane P. LeBlanc,
City Clerk

and much more; and

is formed; now therefore be it

of the FY24 budget cycle.
